Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY ) Holdings Cut by Voloridge Investment Management LLC
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Holdings Cut by Voloridge Investment 
Management LLC
Transcript Daily
March 24, 2019 Sunday 6:08 PM EST
Copyright 2019 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 790 words
Body
Mar 24, 2019( Transcript Daily: https://transcriptdaily.com Delivered by Newstex)  Voloridge Investment 
Management LLC reduced its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 12.3% in the 4th 
quarter, according to its most recent Form 13F filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The 
institutional investor owned 29,028 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 4,077 shares during 
the quarter. Voloridge Investment Management LLC's holdings in Ryanair were worth $2,071,000 as of its most 
recent SEC filing. A number of other institutional investors also recently added to or reduced their stakes in the 
business. 
Advisors Asset Management Inc. raised its stake in Ryanair by 2.3% during the fourth quarter. Advisors Asset 
Management Inc. now owns 8,631 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $616,000 after acquiring an 
additional 191 shares in the last quarter. Advisor Group Inc. grew its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 2.5% during 
the fourth quarter. Advisor Group Inc. now owns 8,999 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$642,000 after purchasing an additional 218 shares during the last quarter. Raymond James Trust N.A. grew its 
holdings in shares of Ryanair by 9.3% during the fourth quarter. Raymond James Trust N.A. now owns 2,858 
shares of the transportation company's stock worth $204,000 after purchasing an additional 244 shares during the 
last quarter. Comerica Bank grew its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 1.5% during the fourth quarter. Comerica 
Bank now owns 16,385 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $1,139,000 after purchasing an 
additional 246 shares during the last quarter. Finally, Intact Investment Management Inc. grew its holdings in shares 
of Ryanair by 4.5% during the fourth quarter. Intact Investment Management Inc. now owns 6,900 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $492,000 after purchasing an additional 300 shares during the last quarter. 
Hedge funds and other institutional investors own 43.68% of the company's stock. RYAAY has been the topic of 
several research analyst reports. HSBC upgraded Ryanair from a "reduce" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on 
Tuesday, January 22nd. Morgan Stanley cut Ryanair from an "overweight" rating to an "equal weight" rating in a 
report on Tuesday, January 22nd. Berenberg Bank cut Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "sell" rating in a report on 
Tuesday, January 8th. Cantor Fitzgerald upgraded Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on 
Wednesday, February 6th. Finally, Societe Generale upgraded Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a 
report on Tuesday, February 19th. Four research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, four have given a 
hold rating and seven have given a buy rating to the company's stock. The company currently has an average 
rating of "Hold" and an average price target of $80.50.Shares of RYAAY[1] opened at $71.46 on Friday. The 
company has a current ratio of 0.91, a quick ratio of 0.91 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.68. Ryanair Holdings plc 
has a 1 year low of $65.61 and a 1 year high of $125.96. The stock has a market cap of $16.74 billion, a price-to-
Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY ) Holdings Cut by Voloridge Investment Management LLC
earnings ratio of 10.14 and a beta of 0.74. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its earnings results on Monday, 
February 4th. The transportation company reported ($0.10) earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, missing the 
Zacks' consensus estimate of $0.25 by ($0.35). Ryanair had a return on equity of 25.18% and a net margin of 
14.65%. The company had revenue of $1.80 billion for the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.80 
billion. As a group, equities analysts predict that Ryanair Holdings plc will post 5.72 earnings per share for the 
current year.  Ryanair Company ProfileRyanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-
passenger airline services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also 
involved in the provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related 
services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car 
hire, and travel insurance through its Website.Featured Article: The benefits and drawbacks of dollar cost 
averaging[2]Want to see what other hedge funds are holding RYAAY? Visit HoldingsChannel.com[3] to get the

Airlines/Brexit: charm defensive
Airlines/Brexit: charm defensive
Financial Times (London, England)
March 23, 2019 Saturday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 18
Length: 321 words
Body
Airline boss Willie Walsh once invoked "magic" when asked how IAG would comply with EU ownership rules.
The EU's transport commissioner - an expert on New Age ideas - seems unimpressed. Violeta Bulc, who studied as 
a shaman, has accused airline groups like IAG of gambling that the UK will not crash out of the EU without a deal.
Her beef is that she has not yet seen their plans for meeting ownership rules. Airlines operating within the EU need 
to show that at least half their shares are held by EU nationals. Such protectionist rules are common across the 
world - though at least the UK has opted not to introduce restrictions of its own after a no-deal Brexit.
The airlines will have six months' grace to reach the EU's ownership threshold. EasyJet is already in touching 
distance, it said yesterday. Ryanair needs a bigger shift. Without the Brits, the share of EU shareholders will fall 
from 55 per cent to 45 per cent. But Ryanair thinks it needs just four months to reach the target. One inducement to 
get Brits to sell would be stripping them of their voting rights.
IAG has greater need of magical thinking. In February, it capped non-EU share ownership at its existing level of 
47.5 per cent. But with a big chunk of shares owned by UK investors, that would rise to as much as 64 per cent 
after Brexit. While IAG has the power to force non-EU shareholders to sell, it thinks it can avoid that. But it has not 
explained how. A statement that it would consider UK shareholders as EU investors after Brexit was dissed as 
"totally absurd" by a Brussels official.
Shareholders, like passengers, should have no illusions about the disruption from a disorderly Brexit. In February, 
IAG's shares fell 7 per cent in two days after the cap on non-EU ownership prompted its removal from MSCI's 
Airlines/Brexit: charm defensive
global equity indices. IAG may well pull a rabbit out of its hat. But it cannot divert attention from the central problem 
for much longer.
Load-Date: March 22, 2019
End of Document

TOP NEWS: easyJet Ready To Suspend Investor Rights In No-Deal Brexit
TOP NEWS: easyJet Ready To Suspend Investor Rights In No-Deal Brexit
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
March 22, 2019 Friday 4:10 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 232 words
Body
 easyJet PLC on Friday said it continues to "stand ready" to activate its no-deal Brexit contingency plan which will 
see the suspension of some shareholders' rights. 
The FTSE 100 budget airline said that in the case of a disorderly exit of the UK from the European Union, it will 
suspend the voting rights of a "small number of shares". This will be done to shares held by non-EU shareholders, 
including UK nationals, on a last-in-first-out basis. 
For the period of suspension, the affected shareholders will not be permitted to attend, speak or vote at meeting of 
the company. 
The plan is needed to ensure easyJet's compliance with EU ownership and control requirements, to allow the airline 
to continue flying across the bloc. 
Currently, easyJet's EU ownership, excluding the UK, stands at 49.9%, below the 50% plus 1 share which will be 
required after Brexit to comply with EU rules. 
Earlier in March, airline peer Ryanair Holdings PLC implemented a similar plan among its resolutions to protect the 
company in the case of a no-deal Brexit. 
Ryanair decided that all shares held by non-EU shareholders, including UK ones after Brexit, will be treated as 
"restricted shares", meaning that they will have no entitlement to attend, speak or vote at any company meeting. 
Furthermore, Ryanair added that the prohibition on non-EU nationals to acquire shares, announced in 2002, 
continues to apply. 
Load-Date: March 23, 2019
TOP NEWS: easyJet Ready To Suspend Investor Rights In No-Deal Brexit
End of Document
Travel & Leisure
Travel & Leisure
Financial Times (London, England)
March 22, 2019 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;FEATURES; Pg. 22
Length: 254 words

FINANCIAL TIMES SHARE SERVICE

Load-Date: March 21, 2019
End of Document
Max woes pile pressure on Norwegian Air Airlines. Strategy test ; Grounding of 737 jet takes toll on share price 
as carrier faces profitability problems
Max woes pile pressure on Norwegian Air; Airlines. Strategy test ; 
Grounding of 737 jet takes toll on share price as carrier faces profitability 
problems
Financial Times (London, England)
March 22, 2019 Friday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;FEATURES; Pg. 12
Length: 868 words
Byline: RICHARD MILNE ;JOSH SPERO
Body
Most of the focus in the aftermath of the Ethiopian air crash this month has been on Boeing, the manufacturer of the 
illfated 737 Max aircraft.
But a different company - Norwegian Air Shuttle, the low-cost airline - has been harder hit by stock markets since 
the crash.
Its shares fell close to 10 per cent on Wednesday on the back of a brutal analyst downgrade from HSBC, bringing 
its total losses since the Ethiopian crash to more than 16 per cent. Boeing is down 10 per cent in the same period.
Norwegian itself had 18 of the 737 Max aircraft, out of a fleet of about 160, and is demanding compensation from 
Boeing for their grounding. But for analysts and investors, the fallout from the crash has raised renewed questions 
about Norwegian's stretched finances and its ability to survive.
Preben Rasch-Olsen, analyst at Carnegie, the Swedish bank, said: "Norwegian is probably one of the most 
financially geared airlines in the world. Things like this hurt a lot."
The carrier has had a difficult year amid intense doubts about its vulnerability after a long period of growth. It faced 
problems last year with the Dreamliner, another Boeing aircraft, and one of its 737s was stranded in Iran for more 
Max woes pile pressure on Norwegian Air Airlines. Strategy test ; Grounding of 737 jet takes toll on share price 
as carrier faces profitability problems
than a month this year because of problems with US sanctions. A potential bid from the owner of British Airways 
never materialised, and the shares are down 70 per cent from their highs last year.
The grounding of the 737 Max could have been even worse for Norwegian: it closed a months-long NKr3bn 
($353m) rights issue to shore up its balance sheet only last Friday.
But analysts say that Norwegian is suffering from more than just bad luck.
"I would argue that the company has no reserves for anything to go wrong - and that's not a good position for 
airlines, as something always goes wrong. Their business model is broken and they're not doing enough to fix it," 
said Daniel Roeska, analyst at Bernstein.
The outlook from many is bleak. Norwegian's shares traded as high as NKr171 last May but closed on Wednesday 
at NKr50.7 as Andrew Lobbenberg, analyst at HSBC, cut his price target to just NKr20. He forecast a deeper than 
expected loss of NKr3bn this year and another deficit of NKr1.1bn in 2020, reversing a forecast of a small profit.
"The losses they are going to incur from the Max problems will see them eat through that equity injection very 
quickly. The profitability of the business is going to be very weak," he added.
The airline, the largest low-cost carrier in Europe after Ryanair and easyJet, made a strategy change this year, 
promising an end to rapid growth in which it started myriad transatlantic services. Instead, Norwegian promised a 
focus on profitability through cutting costs and selling off aircraft.
Mr Lobbenberg said that the groundings paradoxically could be a "strategic opportunity" as it could raise the price of 
the older planes Norwegian is trying to sell, as well as cutting its capital expenditure as its pending orders for 92 
further 737 Maxes are delayed.
There are doubts over how successful Norwegian's strategy will be. Mr Lobbenberg said economies of scale were 
likely to reverse, leading to higher costs, even if weaker routes were cut.
Mr Rasch-Olsen said: "It's not a quick fix that Norwegian is trying to do. Lowering costs to hopefully resume 
profitability. They have a lot to prove before you can be more certain that what they're doing is paying off."
As part of its efforts to save NKr2bn, Norwegian said it would close its base at Palma in Mallorca, affecting about 
100 pilots and cabin crew. But instead of laying off the staff, which would have proved expensive, Norwegian now 
wants to suspend their contracts and in effect put them on unpaid leave for up to a year, according to a letter sent 
by the company to workers in Palma.
Norwegian made specific reference to the 737 Max groundings, saying "it had narrowed our options even further" 
while it also stressed the "seriousness of the situation" regarding its finances.
One Norwegian pilot said it was like "a siege" with the airline trying to "starve them out". The pilot added the 
company was "going for the easy option without consideration of the human cost and inevitable impact of creating 
an atmosphere of low morale".
Norwegian said the suspension was a "perfectly standard measure" designed to protect "the many and not the few" 
among its 2,400 workers in Spain.
It added that analysts such as Mr Lobbenberg did not "have the entire picture" as the company was "well positioned 
to continue to attract new customers, not least in the long-haul market" after the rights issue.
Amid the pressure, changes at the top of Norwegian are coming. Bjorn Kise, chairman, who was joint leading 
shareholder with Bjorn Kjos, chief executive, before the recent equity injection, is to step down this year as analysts 
expect John Fredriksen, the billionaire who underwrote the rights issue, to exercise more influence.
Max woes pile pressure on Norwegian Air Airlines. Strategy test ; Grounding of 737 jet takes toll on share price 
as carrier faces profitability problems
There are also questions about the future of Mr Kjos, 72. "His previous vision for the company is no longer the right 
path forward. I wouldn't be surprised by there being more change," Mr Lobbenberg said.
'They have a lot to prove before you can be more certain that what they're doing is paying off '
Graphic
 
Short haul: analysts expect Norwegian to eat through a $353m rights issue that closed last week
Load-Date: March 21, 2019
End of Document

as carrier faces profitability problems

company was "going for the easy option without consideration of the human cost and inevitable impact of creating 
an atmosphere of low morale".
Norwegian said the suspension was a "perfectly standard measure" designed to protect "the many and not the few" 
among its 2,400 workers in Spain.
It added that analysts such as Mr Lobbenberg did not "have the entire picture" as the company was "well positioned 
to continue to attract new customers, not least in the long-haul market" after the rights issue.
Amid the pressure, changes at the top of Norwegian are coming. Bjorn Kise, chairman, who was joint leading 
shareholder with Bjorn Kjos, chief executive, before the recent equity injection, is to step down this year as analysts 
expect John Fredriksen, the billionaire who underwrote the rights issue, to exercise more influence.

There are also questions about the future of Mr Kjos, 72. "His previous vision for the company is no longer the right 
path forward. I wouldn't be surprised by there being more change," Mr Lobbenberg said.

Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY ) Given Consensus Rating of 'Hold' by Analysts
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Given Consensus Rating of 'Hold' by 
Analysts
Watchlist News
March 21, 2019 Thursday 8:08 PM EST
Copyright 2019 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 692 words
Body
Mar 21, 2019( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Shares of Ryanair Holdings 
plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have been assigned a consensus recommendation of "Hold" from the sixteen research firms 
that are covering the company, Marketbeat[1] reports. Four research analysts have rated the stock with a sell 
recommendation, four have given a hold recommendation and seven have assigned a buy recommendation to the 
company. The average 1-year target price among brokerages that have covered the stock in the last year is $80.50. 
Several equities analysts recently commented on RYAAY shares. 
Cantor Fitzgerald raised shares of Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Wednesday, 
February 6th. Zacks Investment Research[2] upgraded shares of Ryanair from a "strong sell" rating to a "buy" rating 
and set a $83.00 price target for the company in a research report on Tuesday, December 11th. Morgan Stanley cut 
shares of Ryanair from an "overweight" rating to an "equal weight" rating in a research report on Tuesday, January 
22nd. HSBC upgraded shares of Ryanair from a "reduce" rating to a "buy" rating in a research report on Tuesday, 
January 22nd. Finally, Macquarie initiated coverage on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Tuesday, 
November 27th. They issued an "underperform" rating for the company.A number of hedge funds and other 
institutional investors have recently modified their holdings of the stock. Pinnacle Bank bought a new position in 
shares of Ryanair in the fourth quarter valued at $31,000. Quadrant Capital Group LLC lifted its stake in shares of 
Ryanair by 2,727.3% in the fourth quarter. Quadrant Capital Group LLC now owns 933 shares of the transportation 
company's stock valued at $65,000 after buying an additional 900 shares in the last quarter. BRITISH COLUMBIA 
INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT Corp bought a new position in shares of Ryanair in the fourth quarter valued at 
$84,000. We Are One Seven LLC bought a new position in shares of Ryanair in the fourth quarter valued at 
$116,000. Finally, NumerixS Investment Technologies Inc lifted its stake in shares of Ryanair by 171.4% in the 
fourth quarter. NumerixS Investment Technologies Inc now owns 1,900 shares of the transportation company's 
stock valued at $136,000 after buying an additional 1,200 shares in the last quarter. 43.68% of the stock is currently 
owned by institutional investors and hedge funds. Shares of Ryanair stock[3] traded up $0.38 on Friday, reaching 
$73.53. 13,830 shares of the stock were exchanged, compared to its average volume of 628,388. Ryanair has a 
one year low of $65.61 and a one year high of $126.02. The company has a current ratio of 0.91, a quick ratio of 
0.91 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.68. The company has a market cap of $17.13 billion, a PE ratio of 10.43 and a 
beta of 0.74. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly earnings data on Monday, February 4th. The 
transportation company reported ($0.10) EPS for the quarter, missing the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of 
$0.25 by ($0.35). The company had revenue of $1.80 billion during the quarter, compared to the consensus 
estimate of $1.80 billion. Ryanair had a net margin of 14.65% and a return on equity of 25.18%. Research analysts 
Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY ) Given Consensus Rating of 'Hold' by Analysts
forecast that Ryanair will post 5.72 earnings per share for the current year. About RyanairRyanair Holdings plc, 
together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and 
Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, such as non-
flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and 
marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.Featured Story:

in

No-deal Brexit share trade ruling sparks accusations of EU 'land grab' Equities
No-deal Brexit share trade ruling sparks accusations of EU 'land grab'; 
Equities
Financial Times (London, England)
March 21, 2019 Thursday
Edition 1, European Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 19
Length: 548 words
Byline: PHILIP STAFFORD
Body
European fund managers have called on regulators to reconsider plans that would prevent them from trading some 
of the UK's biggest stocks in London in the event of a no-deal Brexit, amid accusations that the EU is mounting a 
"land grab" of UK share trading.
Investors were surprised by a ruling late on Tuesday from the European Securities and Markets Authority, the pan-
European administrator, which detailed some 6,200 stocks that EU-registered investors would have to trade in the 
EU if the UK leaves the bloc without a deal.
The list included 14 stocks whose home listing is in London and which trade overwhelmingly on the city's main 
exchange, such as Vodafone, Rio Tinto and BP. All 6,200 stocks are either EUbased or have a second, highly 
active listing in London, such as Ryanair.
Esma's ruling drew a sharp response from the UK's Financial Conduct Authority, which warned it could lead to 
"disruption".
Executives also said the ruling could clash with requirements for brokers and asset managers to secure the best 
prices for their transactions. London-listed shares often see much higher volumes of trading than equivalents in 
Europe, meaning that big trades can be carried out more efficiently.
No-deal Brexit share trade ruling sparks accusations of EU 'land grab' Equities
"I think it's politically led - this is a land grab at a time of real uncertainty," said Alasdair Haynes, chief executive of 
Aquis Exchange, a UK trading venue that last year set up another venue in Paris in preparation for Britain's exit 
from the EU. "It's good news for Aquis but it's very bad news for investors. Splitting up liquidity is poor for the 
endinvestor."
EU-based fund managers had hoped that regulators would recognise UK exchanges as having "equivalent" 
standards, thus easing fears that an abrupt departure from the bloc next week could create market instability.
Vincent Dessard, senior regulatory adviser at the European Fund and Asset Management Association, a trade body 
based in Brussels, said Esma's rulings were "insufficient".
"We believe this will lead to a fire-sale of securities, which will impact upon the revenues and savings of EU 
citizens. We urge the European Commission to ... grant equivalence to all UK recognised trading venues and for all 
types of financial instruments."
Brokers and asset managers face further complications if the UK applies the same share trading obligation in a 
nodeal Brexit, as it has said it plans to do. In that scenario, a UK broker would not be able to trade Deutsche Bank 
in Germany, for example.
One executive predicted that banks would have to move trading desks into Europe and investors may turn to 
derivatives such as equity swaps, which are outside the scope of the rules.
Others may simply stop trading. "We don't see how it's possible to comply with this other than ceasing to trade the 
[names] affected," said Jiri Krol, deputy chief executive of the London-based Alternative Investment Management 
Association.
Some observers were bemused at how Esma had arrived at its list of stocks that would be affected.
Many companies on the list were unaware they had been included. Nick Burchett, head of UK equities at Cavendish 
Asset Management, said markets simply wanted a smooth and transparent way of trading stocks across Europe.
'It's good news for Aquis but it's very bad news for investors. Splitting up liquidity is poor'
Load-Date: March 20, 2019
End of Document
No-deal Brexit share trade ruling sparks accusations of EU 'land grab' Equities
No-deal Brexit share trade ruling sparks accusations of EU 'land grab'; 
Equities
Financial Times (London, England)
March 21, 2019 Thursday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;FEATURES; Pg. 19
Length: 548 words
Byline: PHILIP STAFFORD
Body

nodeal Brexit, as it has said it plans to do. In that scenario, a UK broker would not be able to trade Deutsche Bank 
in Germany, for example.
One executive predicted that banks would have to move trading desks into Europe and investors may turn to 
derivatives such as equity swaps, which are outside the scope of the rules.
Others may simply stop trading. "We don't see how it's possible to comply with this other than ceasing to trade the 
[names] affected," said Jiri Krol, deputy chief executive of the London-based Alternative Investment Management 
Association.
Some observers were bemused at how Esma had arrived at its list of stocks that would be affected.
Many companies on the list were unaware they had been included. Nick Burchett, head of UK equities at Cavendish 
Asset Management, said markets simply wanted a smooth and transparent way of trading stocks across Europe.

Harris Associates L P Has $1.02 Billion Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
Harris Associates L P Has $1.02 Billion Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc 
(RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
March 20, 2019 Wednesday
Copyright 2019 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 772 words
Body
Ryanair logo Harris Associates L P raised its stake in  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 38.6% during the 
4th quarter, according to its most recent Form 13F filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The 
firm owned 14,358,251 shares of the transportation company's stock after purchasing an additional 4,002,188 
shares during the quarter. Ryanair comprises about  2.1% of Harris Associates L P's investment portfolio, making 
the stock its 10th biggest position. Harris Associates L P owned 6.13% of Ryanair worth $1,024,318,000 as of its 
most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).  
A number of other large investors also recently added to or reduced their stakes in RYAAY. Baillie Gifford & Co. 
increased its position in shares of  Ryanair by 15.7% during the fourth quarter. Baillie Gifford & Co. now owns 
6,792,319 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $484,564,000 after acquiring an additional 920,644 
shares during the last quarter.  Capital International Investors increased its position in shares of  Ryanair by 38.0% 
during the third quarter. Capital International Investors now owns 6,143,716 shares of the transportation company's 
stock worth $590,042,000 after acquiring an additional 1,693,122 shares during the last quarter.  WCM Investment 
Management LLC increased its position in shares of  Ryanair by 2.8% during the fourth quarter. WCM Investment 
Management LLC now owns 4,277,128 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $305,130,000 after 
acquiring an additional 115,663 shares during the last quarter.  Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA 
increased its position in shares of  Ryanair by 27.5% during the fourth quarter. Massachusetts Financial Services 
Co. MA now owns 3,458,575 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $246,734,000 after acquiring an 
additional 745,493 shares during the last quarter.  Finally, JPMorgan Chase & Co. increased its position in shares 
of  Ryanair by 17.3% during the third quarter. JPMorgan Chase & Co. now owns 1,983,410 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $190,487,000 after acquiring an additional 293,233 shares during the last 
quarter. 43.68% of the stock is currently owned by institutional investors.  
Shares of Ryanair stock  opened at $73.24 on Wednesday. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.68, a 
current ratio of 0.91 and a quick ratio of 0.91. The stock has a market capitalization of $17.35 billion, a P/E ratio of 
10.39 and a beta of 0.74. Ryanair Holdings plc has a fifty-two week low of $65.61 and a fifty-two week high of 
$126.89.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its quarterly earnings data on Monday, February 4th. The 
transportation company reported ($0.10) earnings per share for the quarter, missing the Thomson Reuters' 
consensus estimate of $0.25 by ($0.35). The firm had revenue of $1.80 billion during the quarter, compared to the 
Harris Associates L P Has $1.02 Billion Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
consensus estimate of $1.80 billion. Ryanair had a net margin of 14.65% and a return on equity of 25.18%.  
Equities research analysts anticipate that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post 5.72 earnings per share for the current 
fiscal year.  
A number of analysts have recently issued reports on RYAAY shares. HSBC raised Ryanair from a "reduce" rating 
to a "buy" rating in a research report on Tuesday, January 22nd. Zacks Investment Research  raised Ryanair from a 
"hold" rating to a "buy" rating and set a $76.00 target price on the stock in a research report on Monday, January 
21st. BidaskClub raised Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on Friday, November 23rd. Cantor 
Fitzgerald raised Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on Wednesday, February 6th. Finally, 
Societe Generale raised Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on Tuesday, February 19th. Four 
investment analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, four have issued  a hold rating and seven have issued  a 
buy rating to the stock. The stock  has a consensus rating of "Hold" and an average price target of $80.50.  
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Shares Sold by Brinker Capital Inc.
American Banking and Market News
March 20, 2019 Wednesday
Copyright 2019 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 669 words
Body
Ryanair logo Brinker Capital Inc. lessened its holdings in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 
6.4% in the 4th quarter, according to its most recent filing with the SEC. The fund owned 22,659 shares of the 
transportation company's stock after selling 1,548 shares during the period. Brinker Capital Inc.'s holdings in 
Ryanair were worth $1,616,000 at the end of the most recent reporting period.  
A number of other institutional investors have also recently bought and sold shares of RYAAY. Quadrant Capital 
Group LLC raised its holdings in  Ryanair by 2,727.3% in the 4th quarter. Quadrant Capital Group LLC now owns 
933 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $65,000 after acquiring an additional 900 shares in the 
last quarter.  BRITISH COLUMBIA INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT Corp acquired a new position in  Ryanair in the 
4th quarter valued at approximately $84,000.  We Are One Seven LLC acquired a new position in  Ryanair in the 
4th quarter valued at approximately $116,000.  NumerixS Investment Technologies Inc raised its holdings in  
Ryanair by 171.4% in the 4th quarter. NumerixS Investment Technologies Inc now owns 1,900 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $136,000 after acquiring an additional 1,200 shares in the last quarter.  
Finally, Raymond James Trust N.A. raised its holdings in  Ryanair by 9.3% in the 4th quarter. Raymond James 
Trust N.A. now owns 2,858 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $204,000 after acquiring an 
additional 244 shares in the last quarter. 43.68% of the stock is owned by hedge funds and other institutional 
investors.  
Several research firms have recently weighed in on RYAAY. HSBC upgraded Ryanair from a "reduce" rating to a 
"buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, January 22nd. BidaskClub upgraded Ryanair from a "sell" rating to a 
"hold" rating in a research note on Thursday, February 28th. Macquarie began coverage on Ryanair in a research 
note on Tuesday, November 27th. They issued an "underperform" rating on the stock. ValuEngine  lowered Ryanair 
from a "sell" rating to a "strong sell" rating in a research note on Tuesday, January 15th. Finally,            Zacks 
Investment Research  upgraded Ryanair from a "strong sell" rating to a "buy" rating and set a $83.00 price objective 
on the stock in a research note on Tuesday, December 11th. Four equities research analysts have rated the stock 
with a sell rating, four have given a hold rating and seven have assigned  a buy rating to the company's stock. 
Ryanair  has an average rating of "Hold" and a consensus price target of $80.50. 
NASDAQ RYAAY  opened at $74.09 on Wednesday. The company has a market cap of $17.44 billion, a P/E ratio 
of 10.51 and a beta of 0.74. Ryanair Holdings plc has a one year low of $65.61 and a one year high of $126.89. 
The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.68, a quick ratio of 0.91 and a current ratio of 0.91.  
Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY ) Shares Sold by Brinker Capital Inc.
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its quarterly earnings results on Monday, February 4th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.10) EPS for the quarter, missing the Zacks' consensus estimate of $0.25 by ($0.35). The 
business had revenue of $1.80 billion for the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.80 billion. Ryanair 
had a return on equity of 25.18% and a net margin of 14.65%.  Analysts forecast that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post 
5.72 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Will Ryanair gain from turbulent O'Leary moving aside?
Will Ryanair gain from turbulent O'Leary moving aside?
City A.M.
March 20, 2019 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 390 words
Byline: Stephan Shakespeare
Body
EARLIER this month, the chief of budget airline Ryanair, Michael O'Leary, announced he would be stepping back 
from the dayto-day running of the airline. O'Leary identified his reputation as a negative distraction to the airline's 
business and that the move would be a chance to "reboot" the company's public perception after "disappointing" 
profit announcements.
O'Leary was cited as a main cause of the employee dissatisfaction that led to the infamous pilot strikes last year. 
This, alongside O'Leary's headline-making quotes such as, "We don't want to hear your sob stories. What part of 
'no refund' don't you understand?" have made him a divisive character in the industry.
But will moving away from O'Leary be beneficial to 'the UK's least-liked short-haul airline'? YouGov data suggests 
that when it comes to brand perception customers do respond to the actions of management; whether that is 
positively or negatively.
During 2018, 250 flights were cancelled due to strikes over pay and employment issues. Ryanair then refused to 
pay compensation to customers. During this time Ryanair's Buzz Score (a net measure of whether consumers have 
heard anything positive or negative about the brand in the last fortnight) sank almost 10 points from -28.3 to -37.9. 
This fall was also reflected in Impression scores (whether someone has a positive or negative impression of a 
brand) which fell 5 points (-42.2 to -48.4) and Consideration scores (whether someone would consider purchasing 
from the brand in future) which fell 4 points (+21.6 to +17.5) showing customers reacted to management decisions.
Since O'Leary's announcement on 8 March, all of Ryanair's metrics have risen; Buzz scores lifted 8 points (-25.8 to 
-17.3) suggesting a positive public perception. Ryanair's Impression scores also lifted 17 points (-46.3 to -29), and 
Consideration 11 points (+15.5 to +26.6).
Will Ryanair gain from turbulent O'Leary moving aside?
It may seem surprising that brand equity scores respond to news about a company's management, but we have 
often observed that in our numbers.
The effect may be small but it is marked in cases such as Ryanair where the management have deliberately made 
themselves part of the story. The new leadership should make its lead brand assets - low prices and a good safety 
record - the big story, and stay anonymous themselves.
£ Stephan Shakespeare is the chief executive of YouGov
Load-Date: March 20, 2019
End of Document

Harris Associates L P Has $1.02 Billion Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc

Mar 20, 2019( DailyPolitical: http://www.dailypolitical.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Harris Associates L P raised its 
stake in Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 38.6% during the 4th quarter, according to its most recent 
Form 13F filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The firm owned 14,358,251 shares of the 
transportation company's stock after purchasing an additional 4,002,188 shares during the quarter. Ryanair 
comprises about 2.1% of Harris Associates L P's investment portfolio, making the stock its 10th biggest position. 
Harris Associates L P owned 6.13% of Ryanair worth $1,024,318,000 as of its most recent filing with the Securities 
and Exchange Commission (SEC). A number of other large investors also recently added to or reduced their stakes 
in RYAAY.

Headline to come headline to come headline to
Headline to come headline to come headline to
Flight International
March 19, 2019
Copyright 2019 DVV Media International Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: STRAIGHT AND LEVEL
Length: 650 words
Body
Job swaps
Two Irishmen, a Dutchman, a German and a Swede walk on to a stage. The scene is the headline chief executives 
panel session at the recent Airlines For Europe (A4E) summit in Brussels, and the bosses of EasyJet, British 
Airways parent International Airlines Group, KLM, Lufthansa, and Ryanair are asked by moderator Richard Quest 
which of their competitors they would like to run for a week, and why.
Lufty’s Carsen Spohr is first to respond, and plays it relatively safe: “I would take Willie [Walsh]’s job because I am 
jealous of his home market in London,” he replies in reference to IAG’s British Airways, playing it relatively safe.”
Walsh, however, decides to go in harder, picking on a subject that is the subject of frequent industry rumours: “I 
would take KLM and spend that week convincing them that they should be part of IAG,” he says.
KLM’s Pieter Elbers refuses to take up the bait, and instead has a dig at his low-cost rivals: “I would take Ryanair 
and I would show customers that they could really have an enjoyable journey if they pay a few pounds more.”
This prompts Ryanair chief Michael O’Leary to rethink his answer: “I’ve changed my mind in the last few seconds. I 
was originally going to say Carsten so I could [experience] what it feels like to own Germany, Austria and 
Switzerland,” he says. “But I’ve changed [to KLM], so that I can encourage the Dutch government to buy more of Air 
France,” a reference to his earlier comments that state ownership of any airline is bad business, and benefits the 
Irish low-cost carrier.
And what of EasyJet’s chief executive, Johan Lundgren? “I’d take all of them,” he says, to more laughs from the 
audience, before adding: “I noticed that nobody wanted to take us. I take that as a massive compliment.”
Avro-lling back the years
British Airways may be taking inspiration from its past with its recent one-off BOAC and BEA liveries. Is it also going 
back in time when it comes to its fleet? Its London City-based CityFlyer operation, created in the mid-noughties 
Headline to come headline to come headline to
when it sold BA Connect (“Bacon”) to Flybe, is leasing a BAE Systems Avro RJ85 and BAe 146 for summer – types 
it has not flown since replacing them with Embraer E-Jets a decade ago.
Paint what you do
Meanwhile, the flag-carrier’s retro colour schemes sent us scurrying to our archives, and to a time when this column 
really wielded influence.
In 1958, with Britain emerging from the gloomy post-war era, Uncle Roger bemoaned BEA’s lack of imagination 
when it came to painting its newest aircraft. “I have often wondered how many more seats BEA would have sold 
had the Corporation styles its Viscounts, inside and out, more imaginatively,” he wrote. “I suppose BEA consider 
American-style paint-schemes to be flashy and vulgar [but]I am afraid that BEA’s future new aircraft look like being 
as plain as ever. The Comet 3B at Farnborough appeared almost wan, as if someone had said at the last moment: 
‘I suppose we ought to put some markings on it.’”
In 1959, Flight reported that BEA’s Comet 4Bs and Vanguards “are to be painted in the boldest colour scheme yet 
adopted by a British airline”, noting rather triumphantly that it had made a “plea for brighter colour schemes” a year 
earlier.
Union flak
What are we to make of EASA’s recent subtle name change to the European Union Aviation Safety Agency? With 
the UK’s status within the regulator uncertain after Brexit, are the Cologne-ialists making a point ahead of the 
country’s departure date?
Eating Italian
Air France-KLM boss Ben Smith says his airline group is observing the sale of Alitalia “very closely”. In fact, the 
Franco-Dutch combine, Delta, and EasyJet are tracking the flag-carrier’s faltering progress in much the same way 
that a vulture, lion and hyena follow an elderly, sick antelope wondering whether all that effort will be worth it for 
lunch, and whether it might actually leave them with a terrible tummy-ache.
Load-Date: March 26, 2019
End of Document

European ADRs Move Higher in Monday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Monday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
March 18, 2019 Monday 10:42 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 232 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.3% higher at 132.88 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Monday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by pharmaceutical company Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM) and 
Deutsche Bank (DB), which climbed 8.9% and 4.3% respectively. They were followed by biotech firm Forward 
Pharma (FWP) and telecommunications services operator VEON (VEON), which rose 3.3% and 2.8%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by hotel booking site Trivago (TRVG) and financial services firm ING 
Groep (ING), which lost 2% and 1.7% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical company MorphoSys 
(MOR) and semiconductor company ASML (ASML), which were down 1.3% and 1.1%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical company Akari Therapeutics (AKTX) and 
pharmaceutical company Avadel (AVDL), which rose 14% and 4.2% respectively. They were followed by biotech 
firm Autolus Therapeutics (AUTL) and mining company BHP Billiton (BBL), which were up 2.9% and 2.3%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY) and biopharmaceutical firm 
NuCana (NCNA), which fell 1% and 0.9% respectively. They were followed by medical equipment maker Smith & 
Nephew (SNN) and construction materials supplier CRH (CRH), which were off 0.4% each.
Price: 4.87, Change: +0.79, Percent Change: +19.26

TOP NEWS: easyJet Withdraws Process To Explore Alitalia Acquisition
TOP NEWS: easyJet Withdraws Process To Explore Alitalia Acquisition
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
March 18, 2019 Monday 10:26 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 270 words
Body
 easyJet PLC on Monday said it withdrew from the process of forming a consortium for the potential acquisition of 
Italian flag carrier Alitalia Societa Aerea Italiana Spa. 
The budget airline said it took this decision following discussions with Italy's Ferrovie dello Stato Italiane and US's 
Delta Air Lines, the other two potential members of the consortium.
Ferrovie dello Stato is a state-owned company that manages the Italian rail network, while Delta is an Atlanta, 
Georgia-based airline. 
"easyJet remains committed to Italy, as a key market for the company, where it currently carries 18.5 million 
passengers every year and employs 1400 pilots and crew, all on local contracts," the budget airline said. 
Back in February, easyJet confirmed talks for the potential acquisition of the beleaguered Italian airline.
At the end of October, easyJet submitted a proposal expressing interest in Alitalia after the Italian government was 
forced to rescue the company in 2017.
Alitalia went into government-controlled administration in 2017 and was kept afloat by Italian state loans worth 
EUR900 million. The Italian government was supposed to recoup the money by December 15, 2018 and wrap up 
bankruptcy procedures; however it decided to extend the loan to June 30, 2019.
Back in June 2018, both easyJet and fellow budget operator Ryanair Holdings PLC expresses interest in acquiring 
Alitalia, with the latter backing out following chaos caused by strikes and flights cancellations.
easyJet already flies to many destinations in Italy, including Rome, Milan and Naples.
easyjet shares were trading down 0.8% at 1,249.00 pence each.
Load-Date: March 19, 2019
TOP NEWS: easyJet Withdraws Process To Explore Alitalia Acquisition
End of Document
Ryanair Passenger Left With Bloody Nose After Mid-Air Fight
Ryanair Passenger Left With Bloody Nose After Mid-Air Fight
International Business Times News
March 18, 2019 Monday 5:45 AM EST
Copyright 2019 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 534 words
Body
Mar 18, 2019( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)  Two men were 
detained on a Ryanair flight from Glasgow, Scotland, to Tenerife, Spain, after they broke into a fight and left blood 
across the cabin Saturday. Another passenger was left with a bloody nose as a result of the brawl. Footage of the 
fight was shared on Twitter and it shows two men hitting each other as a flight attendant tries to separate them 
while several other passengers scream.In the video, shot by Ben Wardrop, two men can be seen tackling each 
other halfway down the aisle. 
One of them is wearing a cap and a hoodie, while the other one is a younger man in a black top. Another passenger 
can be heard saying, 'Boys stop this. Why are you just sat watching?' The men can be seen fighting for a few more 
moments, before they are pulled off of each other. As the man in the cap is taken towards the front of the plane, 
another man can be seen being escorted by the cabin crew with blood dripping down his face. Several passengers 
said he was trying to break up the fight when he got struck by one of the men. According to Wardrop[1], the fight 
began after a drunk man commented on a woman going to the toilet barefoot. The woman's boyfriend stepped in to 
diffuse the situation, eventually leading to a fight between him and the drunk man. 'Once the plane landed and more 
alcohol was consumed the man and the woman's boyfriend started arguing, both being very drunk they started to 
fight, and the man in the video with lots of blood was trying to get the man to calm down and he got hit on the nose. 
One of the cabin crew, which was a young woman aged about 24, was caught in the middle of it all and was very 
scare, but done a good job on defusing the men fighting,' he said. He further said the staff on the aircraft 'handled 
the situation very well[2].' In a photo shared on Twitter by another user, blood can be seen on the door of an 
overhead luggage compartment. Police from Tenerife were called to the airport after the incident and both men 
were detained.'The crew of this flight from Glasgow Prestwich to Tenerife requested police assistance upon arrival 
after two passengers became disruptive in-flight. The aircraft landed normally and police removed and detained two 
individuals. We will not tolerate unruly or disruptive behavior at any time and the safety and comfort of our 
customers, crew and aircraft is out number one priority. This is now a matter for local police,' a Ryanair 
spokesperson said in a statement to local media.[3] Two passengers on a Ryanair flight from Glasgow, Scotland, to 
Tenerife, Spain, were detained after they got into a fight, leaving one person with a bloody nose. This image shows 
a Ryanair flight before landing at El Prat airport in Barcelona, Spain, Sept. 28, 2018. Photo: PAU

Amy, the PR whizz I'm thrilled to be working with you! It's a great opportunity for our agency.
Twitter Q&As are a terrific way to get brand engagement, a younger audience and raise your personal profile.
Profits? It's tricky to determine the return on investment on Twitter engagement. I see it as magic rather than 
money. As well as metrics, inflection points, RTs! Change your mindset - that's why you hired Spasm PR, to bring 
your brand up to date. Don't think cash flow. Think, profile. Think, reputation. Think viral!
Good point, you didn't get to be Europe's number one herpes drugmaker without thinking about such things - 
#herpes! No, we won't get that hashtag trending. Promise! Trust me.
It won't be like #AskJPM. They are reviled bankers on huge bonuses, you are completely different - a pharma 
company! You help people! Let's get #Drugeze trending!
No, nothing like Ryanair either! Unless you start making sexist comments. You won't, will you? Phew!
So, we have put out the promotional tweet: "What does it take to lead a pharma company? Tweet your questions to 
Stewart, Drug-eze's CEO, 1/4/19 @drugeze #AskDrugeze" Yes, an entire week of focus groups and workshopping.
Ready? Let's go!
'Don't think cashflow. Think profile. Think viral!'; Work Tribes
Wow, generating a lot of traffic. "Is it true that at night you hook yourself up to an intravenous drip that pumps the 
tears of children through your veins.
#AskDrugeze" "What sparked your interest in herpes? #AskDrugeze" Here's a good one. "How do I become a 
pharma bro like you and Martin Shkreli?" No? OK.
"Did you sleep like a feverish baby when you raised your antimalarial drug price by 3000%?" You've gone viral! Can 
I also recommend Spasm PR's crisis management services? Sol, the management guru Hello and thank you for 
downloading the latest episode of The Digest with Sol Santos. I'm Sol. Hi. And remember: "No gut, no glory"!
You may be one of the 1,203 satisfied clients who have restructured their org chart along Colonarchic™ principles, 
from stomach to large intestine. Or you may be a reader of my bestseller Burp! or my latest Straight through the 
Gut: Digestive Secrets of the World's Greatest Leaders.
If so, welcome - and if not, double welcome - to the latest phase in my "Regular Movements" movement. Drumroll! 
I'm going to take these ideas, pivot, reverse back up the digestive tract, and create an entire community around 
mindful mastication!
Did you know, studies show workers who chew their food 32 times are 47 per cent more productive than their 
colleagues? That works out at $47bn of innovation potential simply gobbled down half-eaten and ultimately flushed 
away every year in North America alone.
But - newsflash! - the chomping times they are achanging. State of the art trituration tech can empower millennials 
to change the culture of food intake for the benefit of individuals, companies and society as a whole.
But if we're going to build this compassionate world, one munch at a time, I need your help. Subscribe direct at the 
end of this podcast for bitesized updates, book a 32-Chew-And-You™ session for your team with me or one of my 
growing network of certified wellbeing coaches, or just buy branded apparel, including our new purposeled dribble-
bib, to support the cause online at www.MasticationNation.com.
More about those opportunities later. First, I'm happy to welcome Professor Joelle Sawbubble from Al Dunlap 
Business School, who's going to talk about her latest work, linking swifter swallowing to kinder corporate 
governance.
Joelle, hi!

#AskDrugeze" "What sparked your interest in herpes? #AskDrugeze" Here's a good one. "How do I become a 
pharma bro like you and Martin Shkreli?" No? OK.
"Did you sleep like a feverish baby when you raised your antimalarial drug price by 3000%?" You've gone viral! Can 
I also recommend Spasm PR's crisis management services? Sol, the management guru Hello and thank you for 
downloading the latest episode of The Digest with Sol Santos. I'm Sol. Hi. And remember: "No gut, no glory"!
You may be one of the 1,203 satisfied clients who have restructured their org chart along Colonarchic™ principles, 
from stomach to large intestine. Or you may be a reader of my bestseller Burp! or my latest Straight through the 
Gut: Digestive Secrets of the World's Greatest Leaders.
If so, welcome - and if not, double welcome - to the latest phase in my "Regular Movements" movement. Drumroll! 
I'm going to take these ideas, pivot, reverse back up the digestive tract, and create an entire community around 
mindful mastication!
Did you know, studies show workers who chew their food 32 times are 47 per cent more productive than their 
colleagues? That works out at $47bn of innovation potential simply gobbled down half-eaten and ultimately flushed 
away every year in North America alone.
But - newsflash! - the chomping times they are achanging. State of the art trituration tech can empower millennials 
to change the culture of food intake for the benefit of individuals, companies and society as a whole.
But if we're going to build this compassionate world, one munch at a time, I need your help. Subscribe direct at the 
end of this podcast for bitesized updates, book a 32-Chew-And-You™ session for your team with me or one of my 
growing network of certified wellbeing coaches, or just buy branded apparel, including our new purposeled dribble-
bib, to support the cause online at www.MasticationNation.com.
More about those opportunities later. First, I'm happy to welcome Professor Joelle Sawbubble from Al Dunlap 
Business School, who's going to talk about her latest work, linking swifter swallowing to kinder corporate 
governance.
Joelle, hi!

Amy, the PR whizz I'm thrilled to be working with you! It's a great opportunity for our agency.
Twitter Q&As are a terrific way to get brand engagement, a younger audience and raise your personal profile.
Profits? It's tricky to determine the return on investment on Twitter engagement. I see it as magic rather than 
money. As well as metrics, inflection points, RTs! Change your mindset - that's why you hired Spasm PR, to bring 
your brand up to date. Don't think cash flow. Think, profile. Think, reputation. Think viral!
Good point, you didn't get to be Europe's number one herpes drugmaker without thinking about such things - 
#herpes! No, we won't get that hashtag trending. Promise! Trust me.
It won't be like #AskJPM. They are reviled bankers on huge bonuses, you are completely different - a pharma 
company! You help people! Let's get #Drugeze trending!
No, nothing like Ryanair either! Unless you start making sexist comments. You won't, will you? Phew!
So, we have put out the promotional tweet: "What does it take to lead a pharma company? Tweet your questions to 
Stewart, Drug-eze's CEO, 1/4/19 @drugeze #AskDrugeze" Yes, an entire week of focus groups and workshopping.
Ready? Let's go!

BidaskClub Lowers Ryanair ( RYAAY ) to Sell
BidaskClub Lowers Ryanair (RYAAY) to Sell
DailyPolitical
March 16, 2019 Saturday 2:07 PM EST
Copyright 2019 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 718 words
Body
Mar 
16, 
2019( 
DailyPolitical: 
http://www.dailypolitical.com/ 
Delivered 
by 
Newstex) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
https://www.marketbeat.com/logos/ryanair-holdings-plc-logo.jpgBidaskClub[1] 
lowered 
shares 
of 
Ryanair 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) from a hold rating to a sell rating in a research note issued to investors on Wednesday 
morning.RYAAY has been the topic of a number of other reports. Cantor Fitzgerald upgraded Ryanair from a hold 
rating to a buy rating in a report on Wednesday, February 6th. 
Zacks Investment Research[2] upgraded Ryanair from a strong sell rating to a buy rating and set a $83.00 price 
target on the stock in a report on Tuesday, December 11th. Morgan Stanley lowered Ryanair from an overweight 
rating to an equal weight rating in a report on Tuesday, January 22nd. HSBC upgraded Ryanair from a reduce 
rating to a buy rating in a report on Tuesday, January 22nd. Finally, Macquarie assumed coverage on Ryanair in a 
report on Tuesday, November 27th. They issued an underperform rating on the stock. Four investment analysts 
have rated the stock with a sell rating, four have issued a hold rating and seven have assigned a buy rating to the 
stock. Ryanair currently has an average rating of Hold and an average price target of $80.50.RYAAY stock[3] 
opened at $76.14 on Wednesday. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.68, a quick ratio of 0.91 and a 
current ratio of 0.91. The stock has a market cap of $17.83 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 10.80 and a beta of 
0.74. Ryanair has a 1-year low of $65.61 and a 1-year high of $127.61. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its 
earnings results on Monday, February 4th. The transportation company reported ($0.10) earnings per share for the 
quarter, missing the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of $0.25 by ($0.35). The business had revenue of 
$1.80 billion for the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.80 billion. Ryanair had a return on equity of 
25.18% and a net margin of 14.65%. Analysts predict that Ryanair will post 5.72 earnings per share for the current 
year. Several large investors have recently added to or reduced their stakes in the stock. Advisors Asset 
Management Inc. increased its position in Ryanair by 2.3% during the fourth quarter. Advisors Asset Management 
Inc. now owns 8,631 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $616,000 after buying an additional 191 
shares during the last quarter. Advisor Group Inc. increased its position in Ryanair by 2.5% during the fourth 
quarter. Advisor Group Inc. now owns 8,999 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $642,000 after 
buying an additional 218 shares during the last quarter. Raymond James Trust N.A. increased its position in 
Ryanair by 9.3% during the fourth quarter. Raymond James Trust N.A. now owns 2,858 shares of the transportation 
company's stock worth $204,000 after buying an additional 244 shares during the last quarter. Comerica Bank 
increased its position in Ryanair by 1.5% during the fourth quarter. Comerica Bank now owns 16,385 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $1,139,000 after buying an additional 246 shares during the last quarter. 
Finally, Intact Investment Management Inc. increased its position in Ryanair by 4.5% during the fourth quarter. 
Intact Investment Management Inc. now owns 6,900 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $492,000 
BidaskClub Lowers Ryanair ( RYAAY ) to Sell
after buying an additional 300 shares during the last quarter. 43.69% of the stock is currently owned by institutional 
investors and hedge funds. About RyanairRyanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-
passenger airline services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also 
involved in the provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related 
services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car 
hire, and travel insurance through its Website.Recommended Story: What is dollar cost averaging (DCA)?[4] [ 1]:

CHELTENHAM DIARY
CHELTENHAM DIARY
City A.M.
March 15, 2019 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 44
Length: 366 words
Body
ROD PUTS A PENNY OR OR TWO ON THE GEE-GEES Rod Stewart was getting into the spirit of things at the 
Festival yesterday, strolling into the course clad in tan tweed and cords.
He and wife Penny Lancaster are Cheltenham regulars and will celebrate their 12th wedding anniversary later this 
year.
Also on the radar for Rod is his upcoming tour, which includes another racecourse visit with a concert at York 
Racecourse in June.
The 74-year-old rocker, not shy of a flutter, may want to keep a few quid back for his closing shows in Las Vegas in 
September.
ANDY THEY'RE TOFF!TV personality Georgia Toffolo is a huge racing fan but insists she has no plans get on a 
horse, despite being asked repeatedly.
'Toff', 24, grew up in Devon, used to ride as a youngster and counts some top jockeys as friends.
But, while taking a tour of The Orchard, Festival presenting partners Magners' new activation at the racecourse, she 
revealed why she isn't tempted yet by any offers to get in the saddle.
She said: "I used to ride when I was little and I keep getting asked if I'll take part in a charity race. I just don't think 
I'd be very good so I'm going to stick to watching from the sidelines I think!" WORTH BACKING AN OUT-CIDER IN 
GOLD CUP Gold Cup sponsors Magners will encourage racing fans to look at the silver lining by offering the 
opportunity to swap a 'losing ticket' for a case of its Original Irish Cider.
CHELTENHAM DIARY
Racegoers need only prove they took a punt on the last placed horse by uploading a picture of their slip to a 
dedicated page on the Magn-ers website.
Dou-ble Shuffle and Yala Enki are currently the biggest-priced horses for today's feature race.
THURSDAY IS THE NEW LADIES' DAY Wednesday is the official Ladies' Day at the Cheltenham Festival, but a 
hattrick of female winners yesterday really put the girls in the limelight. Bryony Frost (pictured) drove Frodon to 
victory in the Ryanair to become the first female jockey to ride a Grade One winner over fences at the Festival, 
before Stayers' Hurdle-winning trainer Emma Lavelle and jockey Lizzie Kelly both ended up in the winners' 
enclosure.
Maybe Shattered Love, the only mare contesting today's Magners Cheltenham Gold Cup, will continue the trend.

THE JOCKEY CLUB/PATHE JOCKEY CLUB/PA

European ADRs Move Higher in Thursday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Thursday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
March 14, 2019 Thursday 10:43 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 225 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.42% higher at 131.01 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Thursday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by 3D printing company Materialise (MTLS) and biotech firm Forward 
Pharma (FWP), which rose 4.7% and 4.6% respectively. They were followed by 3D printer company voxeljet (VJET) 
and life insurance firm Aegon (AEG), which were up 2.2% and 1.8%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by biopharmaceutical company DBV Technologies (DBVT), and 
furniture maker Natuzzi (NTZ), which fell 1.9% and 1.7% respectively. They were followed by Deutsche Bank (DB) 
and biopharmaceutical company Ascendis Pharma (ASND), which were off 1.2% and 0.8%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical company Akari Therapeutics (AKTX), which 
jumped 29.8%, followed by insurance company Prudential (PUK), which rose 2.3%. Analytics and information 
provider RELX PLC (RELX) and airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY) were up 1.5% each.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by specialty pharmaceuticals company Midatech Pharma (MTP) and 
Motif Bio (MTFB), which lost 7.1% and 4.7% respectively. They were followed by software firm Endava (DAVA) and 
mining company BHP Billiton (BBL), which dropped 3% and 1.1%. 
Price: 7.45, Change: +1.55, Percent Change: +26.27
Load-Date: March 15, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair resurrects Buzz brand for Polish airline operation Ryanair is to resurrect the 'Buzz' airline brand later 
this year, using it for its newly-established ....
Ryanair resurrects Buzz brand for Polish airline operation; Ryanair is to 
resurrect the 'Buzz' airline brand later this year, using it for its newly-
established Polish operation Ryanair Sun.
Flight International
March 14, 2019
Copyright 2019 DVV Media International Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 224 words
Body
Ryanair is to resurrect the ‘Buzz’ airline brand later this year, using it for its newly-established Polish operation 
Ryanair Sun.
The airline says it will rebrand Ryanair Sun, which was set up last year, with the new identity being introduced from 
autumn.
Ryanair
Ryanair Sun flies under a Polish air operator’s certificate and uses a fleet of 17 Boeing 737-800s.
The Buzz brand was acquired by Ryanair when it took over KLM UK budget airline operating under this name in 
April 2003.
It was originally incorporated into a new Ryanair subsidiary, Buzz Stansted, which operated services using a fleet of 
737s and British Aerospace 146s.
Ryanair has since established a new UK operation, Ryanair UK, with its own air operator’s certificate, as part of its 
efforts to prepare for the country’s departure from the European Union.
The Buzz brand name is to be revived with the Polish operation and Buzz will become one of the four carriers within 
Ryanair Holdings – alongside Ryanair itself, Laudamotion, and Ryanair UK.
Ryanair Sun chief executive Michal Kaczmarzyk says the fleet will have a “new and unique branding” when Buzz is 
launched.
“Our goal is to offer services at the highest level to both customers and tour operators,” he adds.
Ryanair resurrects Buzz brand for Polish airline operation Ryanair is to resurrect the 'Buzz' airline brand later 
this year, using it for its newly-established ....
Buzz will operate scheduled and charter flights and Ryanair aims to expand its fleet to 25 aircraft by summer this 
year.
Load-Date: March 14, 2019
End of Document

CorporaciÃ³n AmÃ©rica Airports announces preliminary year-over-year passenger traffic growth of 5.5% in 
February 2019
CorporaciÃ³n AmÃ©rica Airports announces preliminary year-over-year 
passenger traffic growth of 5.5% in February 2019
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
March 14, 2019 Thursday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 534 words
Highlight: CorporaciÃ³n AmÃ©rica Airports has reported preliminary year-over-year passenger traffic growth of 
5.5% in February 2019.
Body
Passenger Traffic OverviewTotal passenger traffic in February 2019 increased 5.5% YoY, primarily reflecting 
growth of 7.9% in Argentina, 2.8% in Brazil and 8.2% in Ecuador.In Argentina, total passenger traffic increased 
7.9% YoY, mainly driven by 17.2% growth in domestic passengers, benefiting from the launch of several new 
routes and addition to new airlines during 2018, together with a mix-shift to domestic from international travel by 
local passengers. This was partially offset by a decline of 5.4% in international passengers, reflecting continued 
challenging macro conditions. After a full year of operations, El Palomar Airport, our facility servicing low-cost flights 
located in Greater Buenos Aires, ranked 7th in terms of passenger traffic across our network. 
Also driven by low-cost Airlines Norwegian and Flybondi, our Mendoza, C&oacute;rdoba and Iguaz&uacute; 
airports posted increases in domestic traffic of 39.7%, 23.9% and 27.2%, respectively in February.In Italy, 
passenger traffic rose 5.2%, driven by an increase of 5.2% in Pisa Airport mainly related to the addition of 
frequencies by Ryanair and flights by Pobeda to Moscow. In Florence Airport, passenger traffic increased 5.3%, 
due to easier comps as last year traffic was impacted by Air France pilots’ strike, together with the good 
performance of TAP’s connection to Lisbon and the additional flights to Madrid by Iberia.In Brazil, passenger traffic 
at Brasilia airport increased 3.5%, mainly due to an increase of 2.1% in domestic traffic, offset by a decline in 
international traffic mainly as a result of the change in methodology in traffic count by ANAC. Based on the prior 
methodology, international traffic would have increased 32.5% YoY at this airport. Domestic traffic growth remained 
impacted by a reduction in less profitable routes and frequencies by LATAM Airlines, and a decline of approximately 
20% in seat supply at Avianca Brasil. By contrast, Gol continues with its plan to expand operations at Brasilia 
Airport, with new domestic flights to be launched during the first half of the year. International traffic at Brasilia 
Airport declined 10.2% impacted by the new methodology in traffic count applied since June 2018 as discussed 
above. This more than offset traffic growth resulting from the continued good performance of routes to Miami and 
CorporaciÃ³n AmÃ©rica Airports announces preliminary year-over-year passenger traffic growth of 5.5% in 
February 2019
Orlando opened by Gol Airlines in November and the addition of a new direct flight to Buenos Aires during 
December.In Ecuador, passenger traffic increased 8.2%, with international passenger traffic at Guayaquil Airport up 
11.8%, mainly attributed to the continued good performance of the Spirit Airlines flight to Fort Lauderdale introduced 
in March 2018 and the increase in frequencies by COPA Airlines.Cargo Volume and Aircraft MovementsCargo 
volume increased 11.8% in February 2019 mainly as a result a 98.5% increase in Brazil, mainly related to an 
increase in exports, offset by a decline of 7.9% in Argentina, related to the continued challenging macroeconomic 
conditions.Aircraft movements increased 2.5% in February 2019, mainly as a result of increases of 4.5% in 
Argentina and 24.0% in Ecuador, partially offset by a 6.4% decline in Brazil.
Load-Date: March 24, 2019
End of Document
Tiger roars loudest at Cheltenham once more for Gigginstown RACING TRADER ; Jon lees reports from 
yesterday's Glenfarclas Cross Country Chase
Tiger roars loudest at Cheltenham once more for Gigginstown; RACING 
TRADER ; Jon lees reports from yesterday's Glenfarclas Cross Country 
Chase
City A.M.
March 14, 2019 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: SPORT; Pg. 26
Length: 552 words
Byline: Jon lees
Body
TIGER Roll, last year's Grand National winner, made the title of the most versatile horse in training very much his 
own when producing a sumptuous display to win a second Glenfarclas Cross Country Chase.
The hugely popular jumper even brought a tear to the eye of his usually no-nonsense owner, the Ryanair boss 
Michael O'Leary, as he ran out the easiest winner of the Cheltenham Festival so far in a 22-length romp.
It was such a dominant performance that Tiger Roll was cut to 6-1 with Coral and Betway for next month's Grand 
National for which he is now likely to go off one of the hottest ever favourites when he bids to become the first horse 
since Red Rum in 1973 and 1974 to claim victory in successive runnings of the race.
Tiger Roll had already entered Cheltenham folklore having won at three Festivals, capturing the 2014 Triumph 
Hurdle, the four mile National Hunt Chase in 2017 and last year's Glenfarclas Cross Country Chase.
Having warmed up for Cheltenham with a surprise victory in a Grade Two Hurdle at Navan, he came into the race, 
a challenge featuring 32 obstacles including a series of banks, ditches and 'the cheese wedges', rated one of the 
'bankers' of the week.
Yet his trainer Gordon Elliott, who enjoyed eight winners at last year's Festival to finish top trainer, had begun this 
year's meeting with 17 successive losers, among them four favourites including Apple's Jade in the Champion 
Hurdle.
Tiger roars loudest at Cheltenham once more for Gigginstown RACING TRADER ; Jon lees reports from 
yesterday's Glenfarclas Cross Country Chase
Under Keith Donoghue, Tiger Roll was never in danger of joining the list of stable failures. He sat in fourth place for 
much of the way behind the long time leader Kingswell Theatre, taking closer order with eight to jump.
He jumped to the front at the third last and from there it was plain sailing. Donoghue never had to get too serious 
with the nine-year-old who strode right away from the field to leave Josie's Orders, winner of the race in 2016, to 
win the battle for second place with French challenger Urgent De Gregaine by three quarters of a length.
Donoghue was coaxed out of retirement to partner Tiger Roll last year but lost the ride in the Grand National to 
Davy Russell because he couldn't do the weight.
He said: "Tiger Roll is a legend in my eyes. He was my first Cheltenham Festival winner last year and is the horse 
that got my name out there.
"He is some horse and that was some performance on heavy ground. He tanked the whole way and the further we 
went the better he was getting. It was easy. He has the heart of a lion.
"What Tiger Roll has done is serious, winning at four different Festivals in three different races, plus a Grand 
National and Munster National. Today was arguably his best performance. What a trainer Gordon is to bring him 
back here every year because he's had his problems.
"If it wasn't for Gordon, I wouldn't be in this situation and if it wasn't for Gordon, Tiger Roll wouldn't be such a good 
horse either. He is a master of a trainer.
"This is a dream come true. Last year was unreal but this year I can appreciate it more. I think he can win back-to-
back Nationals, but we'll leave that to Davy Russell. I hope he does it for him."
Elliott said: "It's unbelievable.
Tiger Roll is something else. He got us out of trouble because we were having a rough week.
"Tiger Roll is a legend. The way he did that, the way he did it in the Boyne Hurdle, he is class."
Graphic
 
Tiger Roll has now won at four Cheltenham Festivals
Load-Date: March 14, 2019
End of Document
Baillie Gifford Co. Purchases 920,644 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Baillie Gifford Co. Purchases 920,644 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc 
(RYAAY)
Watchlist News
March 13, 2019 Wednesday 10:08 AM EST
Copyright 2019 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 756 words
Body
Mar 13, 2019( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Baillie Gifford .... lifted its 
position in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 15.7% in the fourth quarter, Holdings Channel[1] 
reports. The fund owned 6,792,319 shares of the transportation company's stock after buying an additional 920,644 
shares during the period. Baillie Gifford ....'s holdings in Ryanair were worth $484,564,000 at the end of the most 
recent quarter. 
Several other hedge funds have also recently added to or reduced their stakes in RYAAY. Quadrant Capital Group 
LLC increased its holdings in Ryanair by 2,727.3% in the fourth quarter. Quadrant Capital Group LLC now owns 
933 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $65,000 after purchasing an additional 900 shares 
during the last quarter. BRITISH COLUMBIA INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT Corp bought a new stake in Ryanair in 
the fourth quarter valued at about $84,000. We Are One Seven LLC bought a new stake in Ryanair in the fourth 
quarter valued at about $116,000. NumerixS Investment Technologies Inc grew its stake in Ryanair by 171.4% in 
the fourth quarter. NumerixS Investment Technologies Inc now owns 1,900 shares of the transportation company's 
stock valued at $136,000 after acquiring an additional 1,200 shares during the period. Finally, Raymond James 
Trust N.A. grew its stake in Ryanair by 9.3% in the fourth quarter. Raymond James Trust N.A. now owns 2,858 
shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $204,000 after acquiring an additional 244 shares during the 
period. Institutional investors own 43.89% of the company's stock. RYAAY stock[2] opened at $74.45 on 
Wednesday. The company has a quick ratio of 0.91, a current ratio of 0.91 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.68. The 
stock has a market cap of $17.16 billion, a PE ratio of 10.56 and a beta of 0.82. Ryanair Holdings plc has a fifty-two 
week low of $65.61 and a fifty-two week high of $127.61. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its quarterly 
earnings data on Monday, February 4th. The transportation company reported ($0.10) earnings per share for the 
quarter, missing the consensus estimate of $0.25 by ($0.35). The firm had revenue of $1.80 billion for the quarter, 
compared to analyst estimates of $1.80 billion. Ryanair had a return on equity of 25.18% and a net margin of 
14.65%. As a group, equities research analysts anticipate that Ryanair Holdings plc will post 5.72 EPS for the 
current fiscal year. A number of research analysts have issued reports on RYAAY shares. Zacks Investment 
Research[3] raised Ryanair from a "strong sell" rating to a "buy" rating and set a $83.00 target price for the 
company in a research note on Tuesday, December 11th. Cantor Fitzgerald raised Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a 
"buy" rating in a research note on Wednesday, February 6th. Morgan Stanley cut Ryanair from an "overweight" 
rating to an "equal weight" rating in a research note on Tuesday, January 22nd. HSBC raised Ryanair from a 
"reduce" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, January 22nd. Finally, Macquarie started coverage 
on Ryanair in a research note on Tuesday, November 27th. They issued an "underperform" rating for the company. 
Baillie Gifford Co. Purchases 920,644 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Three equities research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, five have assigned a hold rating and seven 
have given a buy rating to the stock. Ryanair currently has an average rating of "Hold" and a consensus price target 
of $80.50.  About RyanairRyanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline 
services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the 
provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight 
sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel 
insurance through its Website.See Also: What is Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR)? [4]Want to see what
