EasyJet hoards spare parts in Brexit planning Airlines
EasyJet hoards spare parts in Brexit planning; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
March 13, 2019 Wednesday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 13
Length: 369 words
Byline: JOSH SPERO
Body
Low-cost airline easyJet is stockpiling spare parts for its aircraft in continental Europe in case a no-deal Brexit 
severs its supply chains.
Johan Lundgren, chief executive, said easyJet had also been transferring three aircraft a week to its new Austrian 
subsidiary, which now had a fleet of 130. He said the airline was "stockpiling" spare parts for the Austrian fleet, "so 
as part of our Brexit preparations we're making sure we're not reliant on spare parts ... only in the UK".
He said easyJet had "pre-purchased a number of spare parts" and allocated them to the right facilities.
The transfers represent a significant portion of easyJet's fleet, which numbered 315 aircraft last year. Of the airline's 
4,000 pilots, 1,400 now have Austrian registration, along with 3,000 cabin crew. Mr Lundgren said Brexit 
preparations had cost easyJet £10m as well as lost time.
Fellow low-cost carrier Ryanair already has "ample spare parts" around the UK and continental Europe, said 
Michael O'Leary, chief executive. But he conceded a no-deal Brexit would create problems "in terms of moving 
spare engines and wheels" across the continent's land borders, because "you can't fly some of these bigger parts 
around".
An interruption to supply chains would "certainly be inconvenient and would hit passengers", he said, and these 
problems would not arise if the UK parliament avoided a no-deal Brexit.
EasyJet hoards spare parts in Brexit planning Airlines
Ryanair confirmed on Monday that, in the event of a no-deal Brexit, UK investors would not be able to buy its 
shares because of rules requiring EU airlines to be more than 50 per cent EU-owned to retain flying rights around 
the bloc.
Mr O'Leary said a no-deal Brexit would reduce the EU ownership share from 55 per cent to 45 per cent - and that 
UK investors would be likely to be blocked from buying new shares until later this year. "Given the normal flow of 
share sales we think it takes about four months for the 45 per cent EU shareholding to move back up above the 50 
per cent EU shareholding," he said.
Ryanair would restore voting rights once EU investors reached 55 per cent, which Mr O'Leary estimated would be a 
further four months. He also said that the airline would embark on a share buyback in the event of no-deal.
Load-Date: March 12, 2019
End of Document

severs its supply chains.

subsidiary, which now had a fleet of 130. He said the airline was "stockpiling" spare parts for the Austrian fleet, "so

4,000 pilots, 1,400 now have Austrian registration, along with 3,000 cabin crew. Mr Lundgren said Brexit 
preparations had cost easyJet £10m as well as lost time.
Fellow low-cost carrier Ryanair already has "ample spare parts" around the UK and continental Europe, said 
Michael O'Leary, chief executive. But he conceded a no-deal Brexit would create problems "in terms of moving 
spare engines and wheels" across the continent's land borders, because "you can't fly some of these bigger parts 
around".
An interruption to supply chains would "certainly be inconvenient and would hit passengers", he said, and these 
problems would not arise if the UK parliament avoided a no-deal Brexit.
EasyJet hoards spare parts in Brexit planning Airlines
Ryanair confirmed on Monday that, in the event of a no-deal Brexit, UK investors would not be able to buy its 
shares because of rules requiring EU airlines to be more than 50 per cent EU-owned to retain flying rights around 
the bloc.
Mr O'Leary said a no-deal Brexit would reduce the EU ownership share from 55 per cent to 45 per cent - and that 
UK investors would be likely to be blocked from buying new shares until later this year. "Given the normal flow of 
share sales we think it takes about four months for the 45 per cent EU shareholding to move back up above the 50 
per cent EU shareholding," he said.
Ryanair would restore voting rights once EU investors reached 55 per cent, which Mr O'Leary estimated would be a 
further four months. He also said that the airline would embark on a share buyback in the event of no-deal.
Load-Date: March 12, 2019
End of Document
EasyJet hoards spare parts in Brexit planning Airlines
EasyJet hoards spare parts in Brexit planning; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
March 13, 2019 Wednesday
Edition 1, European Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 13
Length: 369 words
Byline: JOSH SPERO
Body
Low-cost airline easyJet is stockpiling spare parts for its aircraft in continental Europe in case a no-deal Brexit 
severs its supply chains.
Johan Lundgren, chief executive, said easyJet had also been transferring three aircraft a week to its new Austrian 
subsidiary, which now had a fleet of 130. He said the airline was "stockpiling" spare parts for the Austrian fleet, "so 
as part of our Brexit preparations we're making sure we're not reliant on spare parts ... only in the UK".
He said easyJet had "pre-purchased a number of spare parts" and allocated them to the right facilities.
The transfers represent a significant portion of easyJet's fleet, which numbered 315 aircraft last year. Of the airline's 
4,000 pilots, 1,400 now have Austrian registration, along with 3,000 cabin crew. Mr Lundgren said Brexit 
preparations had cost easyJet £10m as well as lost time.
Fellow low-cost carrier Ryanair already has "ample spare parts" around the UK and continental Europe, said 
Michael O'Leary, chief executive. But he conceded a no-deal Brexit would create problems "in terms of moving 
spare engines and wheels" across the continent's land borders, because "you can't fly some of these bigger parts 
around".
An interruption to supply chains would "certainly be inconvenient and would hit passengers", he said, and these 
problems would not arise if the UK parliament avoided a no-deal Brexit.
EasyJet hoards spare parts in Brexit planning Airlines
Ryanair confirmed on Monday that, in the event of a no-deal Brexit, UK investors would not be able to buy its 
shares because of rules requiring EU airlines to be more than 50 per cent EU-owned to retain flying rights around 
the bloc.
Mr O'Leary said a no-deal Brexit would reduce the EU ownership share from 55 per cent to 45 per cent - and that 
UK investors would be likely to be blocked from buying new shares until later this year. "Given the normal flow of 
share sales we think it takes about four months for the 45 per cent EU shareholding to move back up above the 50 
per cent EU shareholding," he said.
Ryanair would restore voting rights once EU investors reached 55 per cent, which Mr O'Leary estimated would be a 
further four months. He also said that the airline would embark on a share buyback in the event of no-deal.
Load-Date: March 12, 2019
End of Document

Ryanair announces new Manchester route to Prague
Ryanair announces new Manchester route to Prague
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
March 13, 2019 Wednesday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 319 words
Highlight: Ryanair has announced a new Manchester route to Prague, commencing in October, as part of 
Ryanair's Manchester Winter 2019 schedule, which will be launched shortly.
Body
Manchester consumers and visitors can now book their holidays as far out as March 2020, enjoying even lower 
fares and Ryanair’s customer care improvements, including:Lowest Fares – find a cheaper fare within 3 hours, get 
paid the difference plus &euro;5 MyRyanair creditPunctuality – deliver 90% target (excl. ATC) or 5% off following 
month’s air faresCustomer Care Charter – EU261 claims processed in 10 days, new 24/7 support, connect in 2 
minsCare Improvements – 48-hour free of charge grace period for changes to bookingsEnvironmental 
Improvements – carbon offset programme & plastic free in 5 yearsNew Ryanair Choice – &euro;199 annual fee for 
free seats, fast-track & priority boarding for freq. guestsDigital Improvements – new fare finder, sports tickets, 
bespoke travel guides & faster mobileRyanair’s full Manchester Winter 2019 schedule will be unveiled soon. 
To celebrate its new Prague route, Ryanair has launched a seat sale with fares available from just &pound;14.99, 
for travel in May, which must be booked by midnight Friday (15 Mar), only on the Ryanair.com website.Ryanair’s 
Robin Kiely said:“Ryanair is pleased to announce a new Manchester route to Prague, commencing in October 2019 
with nine weekly services, as part of our winter 2019 schedule. Customers in Manchester can now book flights to 
Prague as far out as March 2020, with our full schedule launching soon. To celebrate, we are releasing seats for 
sale from just &pound;14.99, for travel in May, which are available for booking until midnight Friday (15 
Mar).”Stephen Turner, Commercial Director at Manchester Airport, said:“We’re delighted to see Ryanair offering our 
passengers even more routes to choose from for Winter 2019. Prague is a fantastic city to explore and hugely 
popular with the 22 million people in our catchment area.”

Body
Top stories
•
The Times: Theresa May and Jean-Claude Juncker, president of the European Commission, unveiled a an 
“improved Brexit deal” after the UK prime minister secured changes that she said ensured Britain could not 
be trapped in the Irish backstop.
•
Financial Times: Government is set to replace the accounting watchdog by a stronger regulator with 
powers to issue harsher penalties and investigate company directors.
•

American intelligence if it lets Huawei build its next generation of mobile phone networks.

products.

deadly crash in less than five months, raising doubts over the safety of the planes.

deal to combine operations in the US state of Nevada.

sales model.

Britain more than $1 billion a year if 10% tariffs were imposed on trade between the UK and EU.

from buying more stock, voting on company resolutions or attending annual shareholder meetings in the 
event of a no-deal Brexit.

continues to battle a seismic shift in the sector.

struggling vehicle hire group Northgate.

Stocks rise at start of crunch week for Brexit LONDON REPORT
Stocks rise at start of crunch week for Brexit; LONDON REPORT
City A.M.
March 12, 2019 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 23
Length: 358 words
Body
THE FTSE 100 kicked off a week of key Brexit votes in parliament on a positive note, with financial stocks 
shrugging off fears of a potentially disruptive no-deal divorce while mining companies found their support from 
higher zinc prices.
The main index added 0.4 per cent, shaving off some earlier gains as sterling strengthened, and the FTSE 250 was 
0.2 per cent higher.
After trading initially in the red, the pound gained ground as investors awaited parliamentary votes on Prime 
Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal that could decide on what terms -- if at all - Britain leaves the European Union in 
less than three weeks.
Challenger banks Onesavings and Charter Court Financial Services both surged about 11 per cent, topping the 
mid-cap index.
The rise marked Onesavings' biggest one-day gain since August 2016 and Charter Court Financial enjoyed its best-
ever day.
An index of financial stocks recorded their best day in a week, rebounding after two sessions of heavy losses on 
Deutschebank and Com-merzbank merger talks.
Even more support came from mining companies, which rose as falling inventories and China's stimulus pledge 
helped metal prices climb, and oil majors that rose after Saudi Arabia stood by OPEC-led supply cuts.
London-listed shares of Ryanair were down 2.1 per cent. The low-cost carrier said its board had passed resolutions 
to protect its EU airline licenses after Brexit. But traders cited concerns about possible disruptions from Brexit even 
despite the contingency plans.
Stocks rise at start of crunch week for Brexit LONDON REPORT
Shipping services provider Clarkson slumped 12.5 per cent on its worst day in a year given lower earnings and a 
cautious outlook for financial segment.
Cairn Energy tumbled 11 per cent to its biggest one-day decline in four years after saying it expected a delay in the 
timetable for an award in relation to its proceedings against India. Builder Kier Group dropped 12 per cent on the 
small cap index after forecasting higher debt for 2018.
TOP RISERS 1. NMC Health Up 3.71 per cent 2. Paddy Power Up 3.17 per cent 3. Smurfit Kappa Up 2.84 per cent 
TOP FALLERS 1. Persimmon Down 2.71 per cent 2. Admiral Group Down 1.87 per cent 3. Hiscox Down 1.73 per 
cent
Graphic

FAA Reaffirms 'Continued Airworthiness' of Boeing 's 737 Max 8 After Deadly Crash in Ethiopia
FAA Reaffirms 'Continued Airworthiness' of Boeing's 737 Max 8 After Deadly 
Crash in Ethiopia
MT Newswires Live Briefs
March 12, 2019 Tuesday 4:43 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 187 words
Body
 The Federal Aviation Administration on Monday released a global notice informing airline companies of its 
confidence in the "continued airworthiness" of Boeing's (BA) 737 Max fleet a day after an Ethiopian Airlines plane 
crashed six minutes after take-off in Adis Ababa, killing all 157 people on board.
The incident is being likened to the crash of a Lion Air 737 Max jet which killed all 189 passengers in October of last 
year. The Ethiopian air crash compelled airline companies around the world to ground their 737 Max fleets. Shares 
of Boeing were 5% lower on Monday in the wake of the tragedy.
The agency said that it had just begun its investigation and that there was no conclusive evidence to link the 
Ethiopian plane crash with the incident in Indonesia. 
Despite the agency's assurances, several airline companies have ordered the suspension of 737 Max flights, 
among them Grupo Aeromexico SAB and Brazil's Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes SA, Bloomberg News reported.
Reuters quoted an Irish newspaper saying that Ryanair (RYAAY) would take no action on 737 MAX orders.
Price: 393.30, Change: -6.59, Percent Change: -1.65
Load-Date: March 13, 2019
End of Document
Concerns after plane crash hit Boeing 's shares
Concerns after plane crash hit Boeing's shares
City A.M.
March 12, 2019 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 3
Length: 194 words
Byline: JESS CLARK; EMILY NICOLLE
Body
SHARES in Boeing lost as much as 12 per cent of their value during trading on Wall Street yesterday, as some 
airlines grounded planes following a fatal Ethiopian Airlines crash involving the firm's 737 Max Eight passenger jet 
on Sunday.
China's airline regulator called for all Boeing 787 Max Eight domestic flights to be suspended, while Ethiopian 
Airlines and Cayman Airways both grounded the model. The plane crashed shortly after taking off from Addis 
Ababa on Sunday, killing all 149 passengers and eight crew members.
However, in a vote of confidence for the aircraft firm, Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary told the Irish 
Independent newspaper his firm was not planning to make any changes to its upcoming delivery from Boeing.
Ryanair has ordered 135 of the 737 Max 200 planes, a modified version of the Max Eight, and has options on 75 
more.
The fatal crash followed a similar incident in October last year, when a Lion Air flight using the same model crashed 
shortly after taking off from Jakarta, killing 189 people.
Shares in Boeing closed the session down more than five per cent down, wiping over $12.4bn (£9.4bn) off its total 
market capitalisation.
Load-Date: March 12, 2019

Buy-to-let mortgage lenders Charter Court and OneSavings Bank were the day's top performers after revealing 
plans for an all-share merger.
The "combination should prove materially value enhancing for both sets of shareholders," said Investec, while Peel 
Hunt saw scope for counter offers given sector peers Aldermore and Shawbrook have been taken out in recent 
years.
Cairn Energy retreated after the arbitration panel judging its $1.4bn tax dispute with the Indian government said it 
was unable to give guidance on the expected timing for a decision. Cairn said to expect the judgment by late 2019.
Ryanair weakened after setting out contingency rules for hard Brexit that would see EU shareholders restricted.
Construction group Kier slid after warning that its net debt position at the 2018 year-end was too low by around 
£50m because of an accounting error. The news "further dents management's credibility following December's 
surprise rights issue, and is a backward step in rebuilding confidence in the group's balance sheet position," said 
Stifel.
Experian edged lower after Deutsche Bank argued that the credit checking agency was not priced for a US 
slowdown and advised selling. Bryce Elder

Load-Date: March 11, 2019
End of Document
No Headline In Original
No Headline In Original
Flight International
March 12, 2019
Copyright 2019 DVV Media International Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: THIS WEEK
Length: 274 words
Body
Ryanair chief executive Michael O’Leary would like a woman to take over as head of the group’s mainline 
operation, although his preference for an internal candidate appears to limit his options.
Explaining at the A4E Summit in Brussels on 6 March that he expected the new chief executive to be in place by 
year-end, O’Leary expressed a desire to “break from the past”. At the same time, however, he suggests that a 
current Ryanair employee is the most likely appointee.
“If I had a choice, I’d have a female, just because that would be a very significant break with the past in Ryanair,” he 
says, adding that he thinks “it’s likely to be an internal candidate, because they understand the business”.
Of the nine “senior executives” listed on Ryanair’s website, just one is a woman: chief risk officer Carol Sharkey.
“I would want somebody who has the opposite of my limited skillset,” says O’Leary. “So, somebody female, 
empathetic, caring, kind. As opposed to a rapacious bastard like me for the last 30 years. I think it would be very 
good for the company.”
He clarifies that the process to identify the new mainline chief executive will not be started until Ryanair has 
released its full-year results.
“The plan is, we’ll advertise internally and externally, do the full-year results in May, we’ll run the ads at that stage, 
we’ll recruit some time in September and October and look to have them in place by the end of the year,” he says.
O’Leary suggests that an external candidate is unlikely to take up the role unless an “exceptional” person applies.
As part of a restructuring at Ryanair, O’Leary is stepping up to a group chief executive role.
Load-Date: March 12, 2019
No Headline In Original
End of Document
No Headline In Original
No Headline In Original
Flight International
March 12, 2019
Copyright 2019 DVV Media International Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: THIS WEEK
Length: 274 words
Body
Ryanair chief executive Michael O’Leary would like a woman to take over as head of the group’s mainline 
operation, although his preference for an internal candidate appears to limit his options.
Explaining at the A4E Summit in Brussels on 6 March that he expected the new chief executive to be in place by 
year-end, O’Leary expressed a desire to “break from the past”. At the same time, however, he suggests that a 
current Ryanair employee is the most likely appointee.
“If I had a choice, I’d have a female, just because that would be a very significant break with the past in Ryanair,” he 
says, adding that he thinks “it’s likely to be an internal candidate, because they understand the business”.
Of the nine “senior executives” listed on Ryanair’s website, just one is a woman: chief risk officer Carol Sharkey.
“I would want somebody who has the opposite of my limited skillset,” says O’Leary. “So, somebody female, 
empathetic, caring, kind. As opposed to a rapacious bastard like me for the last 30 years. I think it would be very 
good for the company.”
He clarifies that the process to identify the new mainline chief executive will not be started until Ryanair has 
released its full-year results.
“The plan is, we’ll advertise internally and externally, do the full-year results in May, we’ll run the ads at that stage, 
we’ll recruit some time in September and October and look to have them in place by the end of the year,” he says.
O’Leary suggests that an external candidate is unlikely to take up the role unless an “exceptional” person applies.
As part of a restructuring at Ryanair, O’Leary is stepping up to a group chief executive role.
Load-Date: March 19, 2019
No Headline In Original
End of Document
Austrian plans Vienna fightback Austrian Airlines has committed to "fighting back" against low-cost rivals at 
Vienna airport by strengthening its European route....
Austrian plans Vienna fightback; Austrian Airlines has committed to 
"fighting back" against low-cost rivals at Vienna airport by strengthening its 
European route network, in particular increasing frequencies to Germany.
Flight International
March 11, 2019
Copyright 2019 DVV Media International Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 260 words
Body
Austrian Airlines has committed to "fighting back" against low-cost rivals at Vienna airport by strengthening its 
European route network, in particular increasing frequencies to Germany.
The Lufthansa-owned carrier says that from April it will step up flights to Hamburg, Berlin and Dusseldorf from the 
Austrian capital. In May, Austrian will boost frequencies to Paris and Copenhagen.
Chief commercial officer Andreas Otto says the airline is seeking to offer "a low fare and reliability" to customers, as 
opposed to the "low fare and programmed trouble" offered by rivals. He cites "the frequent changes in the flight 
schedule on the part of new competitors".
In reference the airline's promised "sharp drop in airfares", Otto states: "Customers will be pleased, our competitors 
probably less so.".
Ryanair-owned Laudamotion, IAG budget arm Level and Wizz Air all began operating services from Vienna last 
year and have disclosed plans to grow their operations there this year. Austrian's sister airline Eurowings also flies 
from the airport.
Cirium schedules data shows that on the Vienna-Paris route Austrian will be joined by Air France, Level, Transavia 
France, Laudamotion and Vueling this summer. Austrian, Eurowings and Level all serve Hamburg from Vienna. 
Austrian competes with EasyJet to Berlin and Eurowings to Dusseldorf, while Laudamotion and Level are rivals on 
the Copenhagen route.
Austrian says its passengers numbers grew 7% in January 2019, when an additional 60,000 people flew with it. The 
carrier's passenger numbers grew by 1 million last year.
Austrian plans Vienna fightback Austrian Airlines has committed to "fighting back" against low-cost rivals at 
Vienna airport by strengthening its European route....
Load-Date: March 13, 2019
End of Document
Wizz blames record flight delays on air traffic control Airlines
Wizz blames record flight delays on air traffic control; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
March 11, 2019 Monday
Edition 1, European Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 8
Length: 476 words
Byline: JOSH SPERO
Body
The chief executive of Hungarian carrier Wizz Air has said Europe's air traffic control system is "bleeding from every 
wound" after it had the worst delays to flights on record last year.
Jozsef Varadi called the system's failures "ridiculous" and "outrageous" and blamed air traffic controller strikes in 
France, staff shortages in Germany and a lack of co-operation between national authorities across Europe as 
delays reached a total of 19.1m minutes last year, double that of 2017.
"If you look at the disruption issues behind last summer," he said, "basically it's been very much driven by ATC [air 
traffic control] dysfunctioning."
Mr Varadi said he was "not expecting a significant improvement" this summer, but added that Wizz was improving 
its resilience by putting more slack into its system, such as spare planes.
At trade body Airlines for Europe's conference in Brussels last week, chief executives from major groups such as 
IAG, which owns British Airways, and Ryanair also criticised the ATC system. Willie Walsh, IAG's chief executive, 
called the system "archaic" and said: "European air traffic control is inefficient and starved of proper resources and 
staffing."
Another source of disruption for European carriers is the UK's exit from the EU. Wizz Air has already been forcing 
new non-EU investors to sell shares so it can maintain its European flying rights, a prelude to potentially largescale 
disenfranchisements by European carriers after Brexit.
Wizz blames record flight delays on air traffic control Airlines
EU regulations stipulate that airlines must have a majority of shareholders based in the bloc in order for the airline 
to fly freely around its member states.
Mr Varadi said Wizz had issued two notices to shareholders "forcing sales of shares" to keep the level of non-EU 
investors below 50 per cent. Wizz issued these restriction notices in September 2016 and April 2018 - the second is 
still in place - and Mr Varadi confirmed it would consider disenfranchisements after a no-deal Brexit, when UK 
shareholders will no longer count as EU investors.
He called it a "fairly well-automated mechanism" which "sounds bigger as a concept than it is in actual reality", but 
conceded that it put downward pressure on the share price by constraining demand. Mr Varadi also said the 
London-listed carrier was looking at using a trust structure to maintain its EU flying rights.
A no-deal Brexit will pose problems for airline groups which have a large proportion of UK and non-EU investors, 
including Ryanair, easyJet and IAG. In a trading update in January, easyJet said it had increased its European 
shareholdings (excluding the UK) from 47 per cent in the last update to 49 per cent, while Ryanair has said it will 
use disenfranchisement to reach the target. US private equity group Indigo Partners owns 21 per cent of Wizz.
'European ATC is starved of proper resources and staffing' Willie Walsh, IAG
Load-Date: March 10, 2019
End of Document

Financial Times (London, England)
March 11, 2019 Monday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES; Pg. 8
Length: 476 words
Byline: JOSH SPERO
Body
The chief executive of Hungarian carrier Wizz Air has said Europe's air traffic control system is "bleeding from every

End of Document
Five hot-button topics to watch for ANALYSIS AGM SEASON ; GOVERNANCE Pay, diversity and climate will 
vie for attention, says Jennifer Thompson
Five hot-button topics to watch for; ANALYSIS AGM SEASON ; 
GOVERNANCE Pay, diversity and climate will vie for attention, says Jennifer 
Thompson
Financial Times (London, England)
March 11, 2019 Monday
Edition 1, European Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: FT FM;NEWS; Pg. 10
Length: 1248 words
Byline: Jennifer Thompson
Body
Anger over executive pay grabs headlines but climate-related voting and the push for board diversity will be most 
important to investors when the 2019 season of annual meetings begins in the next few weeks.
In the UK, the new corporate governance code will put some executives' length of service and pension 
arrangements under even stronger scrutiny - and fund managers are ready to flex their muscles.
"Even in cases where you don't win, [a protest vote] can still be an interesting temperature gauge," says George 
Dallas, policy director at the International Corporate Governance Network.
FTfm takes a look at the hot-button issues this year.
Executive pay "Executive remuneration always comes up," says Leon Kamhi, head of responsibility at Hermes 
Investment Management. "Consultations [with investors] have become much better over time but three or four 
[cases] pop their heads up every year."
Company annual reports for 2018 are trickling out, so the full picture on pay - and which executives' packages will 
anger investors most - is still forming.
Five hot-button topics to watch for ANALYSIS AGM SEASON ; GOVERNANCE Pay, diversity and climate will 
vie for attention, says Jennifer Thompson
Ryanair's decision to give chief executive Michael O'Leary a bonus of up to (EURO)99m via a share option deal has 
already raised eyebrows.
Royal London Asset Management, a shareholder in the budget airline, decried the potential award as "wholly 
inappropriate" and "ludicrous".
Meanwhile, shareholders at SSP, the travel food retailer, revolted against the £6.2m pay package of chief executive 
Kate Swann. A third of those who voted at the group's AGM last month came out against the remuneration report.
The Investment Association maintains a public register of listed UK companies subject to protest votes and 
publishes a "repeat offenders" list of companies that appear in two consecutive years.
The remuneration report or payrelated issues were cited in 16 out of 33 companies on the list in both 2017 and 
2018.
"A lot of management teams still haven't got it," says one head of stewardship at a large UK asset manager.
Board tenure In January the UK introduced a new rule as part of an overhaul of the corporate governance code that 
requires chairs to step down after serving on the board for nine years. From next year, UK public companies must 
comply with the code or explain why they have not.
Directors who have served well over this limit include Tim Martin, founder of JD Wetherspoon, who has been 
chairman of the pub chain for 36 years, and Michael Dobson, chairman at Schroders, who joined its board as a 
non-executive in 2001.
Sarah Wilson, chief executive of Minerva, the stewardship consultancy, does not expect to see many protest votes 
on the issue this year. "You normally see a couple of years' lag because it takes time to work its way through the 
system," she says. There may still be some dissent: "Fund managers make their own decisions."
There is already disquiet. Investors holding nearly a fifth of shares voted against the re-election of Mark Williamson, 
chairman of Imperial Brands and on the board for 12 years, at the group's recent AGM. The tobacco group is 
hunting for a successor.
Mike Turner, chairman of Babcock, announced in January that he would step down from the FTSE 250 defence 
group, citing the code and the views of two top-20 shareholders who told him the company would have more 
credibility if he resigned. He has chaired the board for a decade.
Mr Kamhi, however, indicates that Hermes, which manages £34bn of assets, is open-minded on board service.
"What we're looking for is a board that functions well, which has the right skills but is not a club. There's an idea that 
if you've been there too long you've gone native," he says.
He says it would not be a dealbreaker if there were one or two longer-serving directors on a board. "They've seen 
the history, they know what's in the cupboards. We don't want it religiously enforced."
Mr Martin recently told the Financial Times he believed the nine-year rule was "deeply flawed".
Board diversity After years of slow progress on gender diversity at board level, some investors are planning to call 
out the laggards this season.
The Church Investors Group (CIG), a Christian coalition that controls assets of £21bn, has signalled a tougher 
stance at investee companies.
The CIG will vote against the chair of the nominations committee of companies on major indices in Europe, the US, 
Australia and New Zealand unless they have at least one female director.
Five hot-button topics to watch for ANALYSIS AGM SEASON ; GOVERNANCE Pay, diversity and climate will 
vie for attention, says Jennifer Thompson
This is an extension of its targeting British companies on the issue, where the CIG expects at least a third of board 
members to be women.
"We've been increasing our expectations of boards on gender diversity," says Edward Mason, head of responsible 
investment at the Church Commissioners.
Last year it flagged the issue and voted against director elections at more than 136 companies and Mr Mason says 
it will take "a really tough line" on FTSE 100 companies where less than a quarter of directors are women.
Board diversity was one of the priorities for 2019 AGMs in a survey of governance specialists conducted by 
researchers from EY, the professional services firm.
Over half of more than 60 institutional investors said "board diversity, primarily inclusive of gender, race and 
ethnicity, should be a top board focus in 2019".
Climate change "We're seeing climate change feature heavily in this year's season," says Mr Mason.
BP has already side-stepped shareholder anger by agreeing to disclose how its spending and strategy align with 
the Paris climate agreement. It took action ahead of a motion co-filed by ShareAction, the responsible investment 
group, Hermes EOS, Aviva Investors, M&G Investments and Legal & General Investment Management.
Its position contrasts with that of ExxonMobil, which has called on the US Securities and Exchange Commission to 
try to block an investor proposal calling for it to set targets for greenhouse gas emissions.
The US oil group says it is already cutting emissions and that the proposal, led by the pension fund for New York 
state and backed by Calpers and the Church of England, is an attempt to "micromanage the company".
Ms Wilson says the outcomes highlight how European companies are "better attuned" to having conversations with 
shareholders. "One's a British company, one's a US company," she says. "There is a stark contrast in how dialogue 
and engagement operates between the two markets."
Executive pensions Investors are paying more attention to lavish pension deals that further exacerbate the 
difference in income between executives and workers. In part this reflects increasing scrutiny of remuneration but 
the revamped UK corporate governance code includes a stipulation that executives' pension contribution rates 
should be "aligned with those available to the workforce". "There's [more] sensitivity to unequal pay standards 
within companies," says Mr Dallas.
The Investment Association recently wrote to remuneration chairs at FTSE 350 companies. "The pension 
contributions for current executive directors should be reduced over time to equal the rate received by the majority 
of the workforce," said Andrew Ninian, IA director of corporate governance. "Shareholders expect that no 
compensation will be awarded for this change."
"What investors want to see and what we want to see ... is that pensions are in line with the wider workforce," says 
Bruce Duguid, head of stewardship at Hermes EOS, which advises on £389bn of assets. "If [executive pensions 
are] materially out of line and it's a new package, that could well be something we'd vote against."
Load-Date: March 10, 2019
End of Document
Five hot-button topics to watch for ANALYSIS AGM SEASON ; GOVERNANCE Pay, diversity and climate will 
vie for attention, says Jennifer Thompson
Five hot-button topics to watch for; ANALYSIS AGM SEASON ;

Thompson

Thompson

March 11, 2019 Monday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: FT FM;NEWS; Pg. 10
Length: 1248 words
Byline: Jennifer Thompson
Body
A nger over executive pay grabs headlines but climate-related voting and the push for board diversity will be most 
important to investors when the 2019 season of annual meetings begins in the next few weeks.
In the UK, the new corporate governance code will put some executives' length of service and pension 
arrangements under even stronger scrutiny - and fund managers are ready to flex their muscles.
"Even in cases where you don't win, [a protest vote] can still be an interesting temperature gauge," says George 
Dallas, policy director at the International Corporate Governance Network.
FTfm takes a look at the hot-button issues this year.
Executive pay "Executive remuneration always comes up," says Leon Kamhi, head of responsibility at Hermes 
Investment Management. "Consultations [with investors] have become much better over time but three or four 
[cases] pop their heads up every year."
Company annual reports for 2018 are trickling out, so the full picture on pay - and which executives' packages will 
anger investors most - is still forming.
Five hot-button topics to watch for ANALYSIS AGM SEASON ; GOVERNANCE Pay, diversity and climate will 
vie for attention, says Jennifer Thompson
Ryanair's decision to give chief executive Michael O'Leary a bonus of up to (EURO)99m via a share option deal has 
already raised eyebrows.
Royal London Asset Management, a shareholder in the budget airline, decried the potential award as "wholly 
inappropriate" and "ludicrous".
Meanwhile, shareholders at SSP, the travel food retailer, revolted against the £6.2m pay package of chief executive 
Kate Swann. A third of those who voted at the group's AGM last month came out against the remuneration report.
The Investment Association maintains a public register of listed UK companies subject to protest votes and 
publishes a "repeat offenders" list of companies that appear in two consecutive years.
The remuneration report or payrelated issues were cited in 16 out of 33 companies on the list in both 2017 and 
2018.
"A lot of management teams still haven't got it," says one head of stewardship at a large UK asset manager.
Board tenure In January the UK introduced a new rule as part of an overhaul of the corporate governance code that 
requires chairs to step down after serving on the board for nine years. From next year, UK public companies must 
comply with the code or explain why they have not.
Directors who have served well over this limit include Tim Martin, founder of JD Wetherspoon, who has been 
chairman of the pub chain for 36 years, and Michael Dobson, chairman at Schroders, who joined its board as a 
non-executive in 2001.
Sarah Wilson, chief executive of Minerva, the stewardship consultancy, does not expect to see many protest votes 
on the issue this year. "You normally see a couple of years' lag because it takes time to work its way through the 
system," she says. There may still be some dissent: "Fund managers make their own decisions."
There is already disquiet. Investors holding nearly a fifth of shares voted against the re-election of Mark Williamson, 
chairman of Imperial Brands and on the board for 12 years, at the group's recent AGM. The tobacco group is 
hunting for a successor.
Mike Turner, chairman of Babcock, announced in January that he would step down from the FTSE 250 defence 
group, citing the code and the views of two top-20 shareholders who told him the company would have more 
credibility if he resigned. He has chaired the board for a decade.
Mr Kamhi, however, indicates that Hermes, which manages £34bn of assets, is open-minded on board service.
"What we're looking for is a board that functions well, which has the right skills but is not a club. There's an idea that 
if you've been there too long you've gone native," he says.
He says it would not be a dealbreaker if there were one or two longer-serving directors on a board. "They've seen 
the history, they know what's in the cupboards. We don't want it religiously enforced."
Mr Martin recently told the Financial Times he believed the nine-year rule was "deeply flawed".
Board diversity After years of slow progress on gender diversity at board level, some investors are planning to call 
out the laggards this season.
The Church Investors Group (CIG), a Christian coalition that controls assets of £21bn, has signalled a tougher 
stance at investee companies.
The CIG will vote against the chair of the nominations committee of companies on major indices in Europe, the US, 
Australia and New Zealand unless they have at least one female director.
Five hot-button topics to watch for ANALYSIS AGM SEASON ; GOVERNANCE Pay, diversity and climate will 
vie for attention, says Jennifer Thompson
This is an extension of its targeting British companies on the issue, where the CIG expects at least a third of board 
members to be women.
"We've been increasing our expectations of boards on gender diversity," says Edward Mason, head of responsible 
investment at the Church Commissioners.
Last year it flagged the issue and voted against director elections at more than 136 companies and Mr Mason says 
it will take "a really tough line" on FTSE 100 companies where less than a quarter of directors are women.
Board diversity was one of the priorities for 2019 AGMs in a survey of governance specialists conducted by 
researchers from EY, the professional services firm.
Over half of more than 60 institutional investors said "board diversity, primarily inclusive of gender, race and 
ethnicity, should be a top board focus in 2019".
Climate change "We're seeing climate change feature heavily in this year's season," says Mr Mason.
BP has already side-stepped shareholder anger by agreeing to disclose how its spending and strategy align with 
the Paris climate agreement. It took action ahead of a motion co-filed by ShareAction, the responsible investment 
group, Hermes EOS, Aviva Investors, M&G Investments and Legal & General Investment Management.
Its position contrasts with that of ExxonMobil, which has called on the US Securities and Exchange Commission to 
try to block an investor proposal calling for it to set targets for greenhouse gas emissions.
The US oil group says it is already cutting emissions and that the proposal, led by the pension fund for New York 
state and backed by Calpers and the Church of England, is an attempt to "micromanage the company".
Ms Wilson says the outcomes highlight how European companies are "better attuned" to having conversations with 
shareholders. "One's a British company, one's a US company," she says. "There is a stark contrast in how dialogue 
and engagement operates between the two markets."
Executive pensions Investors are paying more attention to lavish pension deals that further exacerbate the 
difference in income between executives and workers. In part this reflects increasing scrutiny of remuneration but 
the revamped UK corporate governance code includes a stipulation that executives' pension contribution rates 
should be "aligned with those available to the workforce". "There's [more] sensitivity to unequal pay standards 
within companies," says Mr Dallas.
The Investment Association recently wrote to remuneration chairs at FTSE 350 companies. "The pension 
contributions for current executive directors should be reduced over time to equal the rate received by the majority 
of the workforce," said Andrew Ninian, IA director of corporate governance. "Shareholders expect that no 
compensation will be awarded for this change."
"What investors want to see and what we want to see ... is that pensions are in line with the wider workforce," says 
Bruce Duguid, head of stewardship at Hermes EOS, which advises on £389bn of assets. "If [executive pensions 
are] materially out of line and it's a new package, that could well be something we'd vote against."

Ryanair to Restrict Voting Rights of British Shareholders In Preparation for No-Deal Brexit
Ryanair to Restrict Voting Rights of British Shareholders In Preparation for 
No-Deal Brexit
MT Newswires Live Briefs
March 11, 2019 Monday 7:27 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 110 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYAAY) said pre-market Monday that the board has passed a resolution to restrict the voting rights of 
British shareholders if the UK exits the European Union without an agreement on future relations.
The move to restrict British shareholders' rights is to ensure the budget carrier remains majority EU-owned and to 
protect its European operating licenses after the UK leaves the EU, the company said in a statement.
Non-EU shareholders, including those from the UK after March 29, will also be barred from voting or taking part at 
any Ryanair general meeting, the Irish-based low-fare airline company added.
Price: 72.00, Change: -1.25, Percent Change: -1.71
Load-Date: March 12, 2019
End of Document
TIGER IS ON AN UNSTOPPABLE ROLL Geoff Lester on Tiger Roll ahead of his tilt at a fourth Cheltenham 
Festival success
TIGER IS ON AN UNSTOPPABLE ROLL; Geoff Lester on Tiger Roll ahead of 
his tilt at a fourth Cheltenham Festival success
City A.M.
March 11, 2019 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES; Pg. 28
Length: 860 words
Byline: Geoff Lesteron
Body
RYANAIR boss Michael O'Leary can afford to shop at Harrods rather than Primark, but it is one of his bargain-
basement equine purchases who is likely to grab the headlines at this week's Cheltenham Festival.
Tiger Roll is no oil-painting. In fact, O'Leary once described him as "a little rat of a thing".
However, his brother Eddie, who is entrusted with the cheque book at the thoroughbred sales, saw enough of this 
pocket-sized gelding as a threeyear-old to purchase him for the powerful Gigginstown House Stud.
Have a look at Tiger Roll yourself in the paddock before he defends his crown in the Glenfarclas Cross Country 
Chase on Wednesday.
You would never have guessed that this little fella would make those supposedly formidable fences at Aintree last 
year resemble dandy brushes as he sailed over Becher's Brook and The Chair en route to a glorious Grand 
National victory.
They might put a statue up at Cheltenham one day, and possibly Aintree, too.
Winning three races at the Festival is one thing, but when they are all so completely different, it beggars' belief.
Triumph Hurdle maybe, four-mile National Hunt Chase no way and then the unique Glenfarclas Cross Country as a 
stepping-stone to success in the greatest steeplechase on the globe at Aintree. Bring on the men in white coats.
TIGER IS ON AN UNSTOPPABLE ROLL Geoff Lester on Tiger Roll ahead of his tilt at a fourth Cheltenham 
Festival success
Like another Aintree hero, the legendary Red Rum, Tiger Roll was bred to be a Flat horse.
He was sired by Derby winner Authorized and bought by Godolphin for 70,000gns at the Tattersalls Yearling Sales.
The Tiger never ran for the boys in blue and 12 months later was bought by West Country jumps trainer Nigel 
Hawke, himself an Aintree hero, having ridden Seagram to victory in the National in 1991.
Hawke struck lucky at the first time of asking when Tiger Roll won a small race at Market Rasen on his debut.
However, the trainer immediately cashed in his chips and made a quick killing, sending him back to the sales, 
where O'Leary bought him for £80,000.
"I bought him thinking he might have a squeak in a race like the Fred Winter," said O'Leary reflecting on arguably 
his best-ever purchase."But when he finished second to Guitar Pete on his first run for us at Leopardstown, we 
rerouted him for the Grade One Triumph Hurdle at the Festival, and the rest is history!
"He only stands at 15.2 hands, but he's been amazing, simply fantastic and he has endless stamina."
Hopes that winning the Triumph might be a prelude to beating the big boys in the Champion Hurdle proved short-
lived, as Tiger Roll's limitations as a timber-topper were exposed by Hurricane Fly and company in the Irish 
equivalent.
"He was falling between two stools at the hurdling game," said O'Leary taking up the story.
"So, we felt we had nothing to lose by trying him over fences, despite his lack of size."
Tiger Roll might not be built for chasing, but he has shown he is nimble at the larger obstacles, and, though he can 
sometimes be too brave for his own good, he seems to have that sixth sense in that he knows at which fences he 
can take liberties and which he can't.
Having won his first two races at Ballinrobe and Kilbeggan, Tiger Roll convinced trainer Gordon Elliott that he 
"might be half-decent", and when they stepped him up in distance he bolted up at Limerick. Therefore, what 
seemed to some a crazy plan for a Triumph Hurdle winner was duly hatched, with the longest race at the Festival 
earmarked as his spring target.
Yet, despite arriving at Cheltenham without having seen a racecourse in five months, Tiger Roll survived a few hairy 
moments over the 25 fences and gave amateur Lisa O'Neill a moment she will never forget when scoring at 16/1. 
Where shall we go next pondered Elliott and the O'Learys, and it was decided to try Tiger Roll on the Cross Country 
course at Cheltenham, a unique race with its twists and turns, taking in banks, ditches, rails and even a cheese-
wedge.
The Tiger looked somewhat mystified when he tried it out at the December meeting, but he got around safely and 
when he went back for the Glenfarclassponsored marathon at the Festival he was far more streetwise and duly 
dotted up.
However, when the O'Learys revealed in the Cheltenham winner's enclosure that the National was the aim, the 
press corps thought they had misheard the comment.
We ought to have known better. Apart from having his jockey knocked over in a melee at the second last at Galway 
one day, Tiger Roll had never been on the floor in 30 races, so even a first ever trip to Liverpool was not going to 
send him scurrying for the worry-beads.
Davy Russell still becomes emotional when he reflects on that Aintree glory. "I wouldn't have been surprised if he 
had fallen at the first fence as he can be shockingly brave, but at the start he was so focused that I knew we were in 
business. What a day!" Dismissed as a 25/1 no-hoper when he returned from his winter break in a hurdle race at 
TIGER IS ON AN UNSTOPPABLE ROLL Geoff Lester on Tiger Roll ahead of his tilt at a fourth Cheltenham 
Festival success
Navan last month, Tiger Roll never broke sweat, clocking up a 10th career success and taking his earnings to just 
shy of £1 million.
He is back chasing more of Glenfarclas' money this week and is odds-on this time. Even the bookmakers have 
learned to respect one of the most popular jump horses in training.
Graphic
 
Tiger Roll brushed through the last on his way to victory in last year's Glenfarclas Cross Country Chase

Victory Capital Management Inc. Has $72,000 Position in Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
Victory Capital Management Inc. Has $72,000 Position in Ryanair Holdings 
plc (RYAAY)

March 10, 2019 Sunday 5:06 PM EST
Copyright 2019 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 739 words
Body
Mar 10, 2019( Transcript Daily: https://transcriptdaily.com Delivered by Newstex)  Victory Capital Management Inc. 
trimmed its position in Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 64.9% during the 4th quarter, according to the 
company in its most recent Form 13F filing with the Securities ...change Commission. The firm owned 1,016 shares 
of the transportation company's stock after selling 1,878 shares during the quarter. 
Victory Capital Management Inc.'s holdings in Ryanair were worth $72,000 as of its most recent filing with the 
Securities ...change Commission. Several other hedge funds and other institutional investors have also recently 
modified their holdings of the stock. Quadrant Capital Group LLC boosted its holdings in Ryanair by 2,727.3% in the 
fourth quarter. Quadrant Capital Group LLC now owns 933 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$65,000 after acquiring an additional 900 shares in the last quarter. We Are One Seven LLC bought a new stake in 
Ryanair in the fourth quarter valued at $116,000. Raymond James Trust N.A. bought a new stake in Ryanair in the 
third quarter valued at $251,000. Freestone Capital Holdings LLC boosted its holdings in Ryanair by 17.2% in the 
third quarter. Freestone Capital Holdings LLC now owns 5,355 shares of the transportation company's stock valued 
at $514,000 after acquiring an additional 785 shares in the last quarter. Finally, PNC Financial Services Group Inc. 
boosted its holdings in Ryanair by 95.5% in the third quarter. PNC Financial Services Group Inc. now owns 5,358 
shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $515,000 after acquiring an additional 2,617 shares in the 
last quarter. 43.89% of the stock is currently owned by institutional investors. Shares of RYAAY stock[1] traded 
down $2.03 during mid-day trading on Friday, reaching $73.25. 458,272 shares of the company's stock traded 
hands, compared to its average volume of 834,650. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 12 month low of $65.61 and a 12 
month high of $127.61. The stock has a market cap of $17.63 billion, a PE ratio of 10.39 and a beta of 0.82. The 
company has a current ratio of 0.91, a quick ratio of 0.91 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.68. Ryanair 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its earnings results on Monday, February 4th. The transportation company 
reported ($0.10) EPS for the quarter, missing the Zacks' consensus estimate of $0.25 by ($0.35). The business had 
revenue of $1.80 billion for the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.80 billion. Ryanair had a net 
margin of 14.65% and a return on equity of 25.18%. On average, sell-side analysts forecast that Ryanair Holdings 
plc will post 5.72 earnings per share for the current fiscal year. RYAAY has been the topic of several recent analyst 
reports. TheStreet cut shares of Ryanair from a "b-" rating to a "c+" rating in a report on Thursday, November 15th. 
BidaskClub upgraded shares of Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on Friday, November 23rd. 
Macquarie began coverage on shares of Ryanair in a report on Tuesday, November 27th. They set an 
"underperform" rating on the stock. Zacks Investment Research[2] upgraded shares of Ryanair from a "strong sell" 
rating to a "buy" rating and set a $83.00 target price on the stock in a report on Tuesday, December 11th. Finally,

Berenberg Bank cut shares of Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "sell" rating in a report on Tuesday, January 8th. 
Three research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, five have given a hold rating and seven have given 
a buy rating to the company. The company currently has a consensus rating of "Hold" and a consensus price target 
of $80.50.  Ryanair ProfileRyanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline 
services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the 
provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight 
sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel

O'Leary confesses he is a Ryanair 'negative'; Airlines ; Chief says need now is to 'shut up and deliver' as he 
prepares for move upstairs
O'Leary confesses he is a Ryanair 'negative'; Airlines ; Chief says need now 
is to 'shut up and deliver' as he prepares for move upstairs
Financial Times (London, England)
March 9, 2019 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 16
Length: 433 words
Byline: JOSH SPERO
Body
Michael O'Leary, chief executive of Ryanair, said his combative reputation had been a negative distraction for the 
airline and was part of the reason he was stepping back from the day-to-day running of the airline.
Mr O'Leary said: "I think one of the negatives of Ryanair is its association with me. I'm an easy person to target ... 
Too much of the negativity that attracts itself to Ryanair attaches itself because of something stupid I said 25 years 
ago."
Mr O'Leary has courted controversy throughout his career.
He once claimed "hell will freeze over" before he would recognise trade unions. He has drawn criticism over a 
potential (EURO)99m bonus, and has had to defend the airline's chairman, David Bonderman, who has been in 
post for more than 20 years, against an investor revolt.
In a new role as head of Ryanair Holdings, Mr O'Leary will oversee the chiefs of the main Ryanair carrier, as well as 
Laudamotion (based in Austria), Ryanair Sun (Poland) and Ryanair UK, the entity formed to surmount obstacles 
thrown up by Brexit.
O'Leary confesses he is a Ryanair 'negative'; Airlines ; Chief says need now is to 'shut up and deliver' as he 
prepares for move upstairs
He will be responsible for decisions including M&A opportunities, costs, and buying aircraft. But he will no longer be 
at the forefront of Ryanair's day-to-day affairs. He said the move was a chance to "reboot" the company's reputation 
as it introduced improvements from a customer charter.
"What we need to do for the next year, certainly through 2019, is shut up and deliver," he said. "In the past, we 
might have spent too much time talking about it and not enough time delivering it."
In the three months to December 2018, Ryanair made a "disappointing" (EURO)22m pre-tax loss, a swing from a 
(EURO)113m profit the year before. Revenue for the quarter rose 9 per cent to (EURO)1.53bn, and it reaffirmed 
January's warning that full-year profit would be in the range of (EURO)1bn-(EURO)1.1bn.
Mr O'Leary said Ryanair was keen to raise the number of female pilots it employed, currently 4 per cent, which led 
to a gender pay gap of 72 per cent last year, worst in the sector. He wanted to double the number of female pilots in 
the next three years, but the gender pay measurement, as devised by the government, was "not a meaningful 
figure. It's entirely bogus ... This entirely arbitrary, meaningless number". What was critical, he said was "that you 
have equal pay. We pay our male cabin crew exactly what we pay our female cabin crew. We pay our female pilots 
exactly what we pay our male pilots."
Ryanair is looking at establishing an apprenticeship scheme for female pilots in the next 12-18 months, Mr O'Leary 
said, adding that 10 per cent of new pilots were female.

European ADRs Move Lower in Friday Trading
European ADRs Move Lower in Friday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
March 8, 2019 Friday 10:58 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 213 words
Body
 American depositary Receipts of European stocks were trading 0.59% lower at 127.20 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Friday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by telecommunication companies VEON (VEON) and Orange (ORAN), 
which climbed 1.9% and 1.7% respectively. They were followed by pharmaceutical company Oasmia 
Pharmaceutical (OASM) and telecommunications operator Ericsson (ERIC), which rose 1.6% and 1.4%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by biotech company Forward Pharma (FWP) and biopharmaceutical 
company Cellectis (CLLS), which fell 4.9% and 2.7% respectively. They were followed by financial services firm 
ING Groep (ING) and telecommunications operator Telecom Italia (TI), which were off 2.2% and 1%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical company NuCana (NCNA) which rose 6.1%. 
Unilever (UL) and telecommunications provider Vodafone Group (VOD) rose 0.9% and 0.8%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by specialty pharmaceutical company  Midatech Pharma (MTP) and 
insurance firm Prudential (PUK), which lost 6.2% and 2.4% respectively. They were followed by airline operator 
Ryanair (RYAAY) and Barclays Bank (BCS), which were down 2.3% and 2.1%.
Price: 12.99, Change: +0.75, Percent Change: +6.11

Great West Life Assurance Co. Can Boosts Position in Ryanair Holdings plc 
(RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
March 8, 2019 Friday
Copyright 2019 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 705 words
Body
Ryanair logo Great West Life Assurance Co. Can boosted its holdings in  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) 
by 106.5% in the 4th quarter, according to the company in its most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange 
Commission. The firm owned 461,409 shares of the transportation company's stock after purchasing an additional 
238,006 shares during the quarter. Great West Life Assurance Co. Can owned about 0.20% of Ryanair worth 
$31,508,000 at the end of the most recent quarter.  
A number of other hedge funds and other institutional investors have also bought and sold shares of RYAAY. 
Russell Investments Group Ltd. raised its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 7.0% during the 3rd quarter. Russell 
Investments Group Ltd. now owns 176,550 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $17,039,000 after 
purchasing an additional 11,533 shares during the period.  Victory Capital Management Inc. purchased a new 
position in  Ryanair during the 3rd quarter valued at about $278,000.  Comerica Bank grew its holdings in  Ryanair 
by 6.7% during the 3rd quarter. Comerica Bank now owns 16,139 shares of the transportation company's stock 
valued at $1,343,000 after buying an additional 1,008 shares in the last quarter.  JPMorgan Chase & Co. grew its 
holdings in  Ryanair by 17.3% during the 3rd quarter. JPMorgan Chase & Co. now owns 1,983,410 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $190,487,000 after buying an additional 293,233 shares in the last 
quarter.  Finally, MML Investors Services LLC grew its holdings in  Ryanair by 48.5% during the 3rd quarter. MML 
Investors Services LLC now owns 9,568 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $919,000 after 
buying an additional 3,127 shares in the last quarter. 43.89% of the stock is owned by institutional investors and 
hedge funds.  
RYAAY stock  opened at $75.28 on Friday. Ryanair Holdings plc has a fifty-two week low of $65.61 and a fifty-two 
week high of $127.61. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.68, a quick ratio of 0.91 and a current ratio of 
0.91. The stock has a market capitalization of $17.63 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 10.68 and a beta of 0.82.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its earnings results on Monday, February 4th. The transportation company 
reported ($0.10) earnings per share for the quarter, missing analysts' consensus estimates of $0.25 by ($0.35). 
Ryanair had a net margin of 14.65% and a return on equity of 25.18%. The firm had revenue of $1.80 billion during 
the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.80 billion.  On average, equities analysts predict that  
Ryanair Holdings plc will post 5.72 earnings per share for the current year.  
A number of research analysts have weighed in on the company. Raymond James raised Ryanair from a "market 
perform" rating to an "outperform" rating and set a $85.00 target price for the company in a report on Wednesday,

January 30th. They noted that the move was a valuation call. Morgan Stanley lowered Ryanair from an "overweight" 
rating to an "equal weight" rating in a report on Tuesday, January 22nd. Cantor Fitzgerald raised Ryanair from a 
"hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on Wednesday, February 6th. Berenberg Bank lowered Ryanair from a 
"hold" rating to a "sell" rating in a report on Tuesday, January 8th. Finally, Zacks Investment Research   reissued a 
"hold" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Monday, December 31st. Three investment analysts have rated the 
stock with a sell rating, five have assigned  a hold rating and seven have given a buy rating to the company. 
Ryanair  has an average rating of "Hold" and an average target price of $80.50.  
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Europe's  E airlines lament lack of female engineers and pilots Two of Europe's biggest airline groups would 
like to see more women taking up engineering and pi....
Europe's  E airlines lament lack of female engineers and pilots; Two of 
Europe's biggest airline groups would like to see more women taking up 
engineering and pilot roles, but cite a lack of female applicants that is 
making progress tough.
Flight International
March 8, 2019
Copyright 2019 DVV Media International Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 557 words
Body
Two of Europe's biggest airline groups would like to see more women taking up engineering and pilot roles, but cite 
a lack of female applicants that is making progress tough.
"We are still finding that when we advertise for jobs we are getting 70%, 80% male applicants," said IAG chief 
executive Willie Walsh during a panel discussion at the A4E Aviation Summit in Brussels on 6 March. "It should be 
50:50. And I can't understand why it wouldn't be 50:50, other than we are just not yet convincing young women that 
aviation holds opportunities for them."
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary says his airline likewise finds that applicants for pilot roles tend to be 
overwhelmingly male. "We do recruitment days for pilot cadets – it's 90% male and 10% female," he says. "You do 
a recruitment day for cabin crew, it's the other way around: it's 80-20 female-male. We need to encourage more 
women to consider [airline] pilot as a career."
He argues: "There’s nothing wrong with the gender balance in aviation. In fact, it’s heavily skewed towards females, 
but they are generally on the cabin-crew side."
At the same event, Boeing's senior vice-president of commercial sales and marketing Ihssane Mounir suggested 
that the airframer had found some success in improving the gender balance in engineering roles by educating girls 
about careers in aviation from a young age.
"It had to be a deliberate plan to do it," Mounir says. "You had to go work at the lower levels, the high-school levels, 
before high-school levels, and get young ladies very interested in the engineering world and making sure that they 
feel comfortable doing it.
Europe's  E airlines lament lack of female engineers and pilots Two of Europe's biggest airline groups would 
like to see more women taking up engineering and pi....
"I've got two young daughters and at the weekends I take them to the factory and show them around," he adds. 
"They too can do this."
Walsh agrees that the "fascinating challenge" of attracting more women into the industry can only be addressed by 
convincing young girls to consider a career in aviation.
"We're out there in the schools – and you've got to get into the schools because we've got to get them at an early 
age get them thinking about aviation, get them thinking about engineering, get them thinking about flying as 
opportunities for them.
"This is a job that everybody needs to participate in," Walsh adds. "We have a responsibility to talk about the 
opportunities and make sure that what has been historically seen as a male-dominated industry addresses that."
He cites the example of the pilot gender mix at Aer Lingus. The carrier recruited its first female pilot in 1977, Walsh 
recalls, and about one in 10 such positions today are filled by women.
"It has taken over 40 years to get from zero to 10%," he says. "It is unacceptable, but there is no simple, easy 
solution."
The pay and conditions afforded to pilots should, in O'Leary's view, make the role "a great career for someone with 
a family".
He notes: "You do five [days] on, four off... You are limited to 900 hours a year – 18-and-a-half hours a week – and 
you get paid 200 grand a year. We need to communicate that message more actively to women."
O'Leary – whose airline has been mired in negotiations with pilot unions across Europe in recent months – 
concludes: "If we had more female pilots, you'd have a generally more sensible pilot body anyway, because women 
tend to be more intelligent and more sensible than men at the best of times."
Load-Date: March 8, 2019

Flying rights to be protected in no-deal Brexit
Flying rights to be protected in no-deal Brexit
City A.M.
March 8, 2019 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 8
Length: 261 words
Byline: ALEXANDRA ROGERS
Body
THE UK government has said it will match the EU's offer to protect flying rights in the event of a no-deal Brexit, 
allowing planes to take off unhindered after 29 March.
The Department for Transport (DFT) said yesterday it had "adopted this approach to provide reassurance and 
minimise disruption - providing a cushion during which future air services arrangements can be negotiated". The 
deal comes after the EU announced last December that flights from the UK into and over the EU would be allowed 
for 12 months to enable "basic connectivity" if the UK leaves the bloc without a deal.
As well as the 12-month guarantee, the EU proposed that regulation be extended by about nine months to ensure 
that certain aviation licences remain valid.
"The UK believes restrictions on ownership and control in aviation are outdated, and do not reflect the reality of the 
global capital markets," the DFT said.
The government said the proposals were a no-deal contingency measure and would only come into force if it failed 
to reach a negotiated withdrawal from the EU.
The announcement was welcomed by airlines, who said it gave passengers and cargo operators "certainty and 
confidence".
Tim Alderslade, chief executive of Airlines UK, which represents airlines including Easyjet, Ryanair and British 
Airways, said: "We welcome that the UK has confirmed its plans to allow flights to continue in a no-deal scenario, 
as the EU has also done.
Flying rights to be protected in no-deal Brexit
"This gives passengers and cargo operators the certainty and confidence that they can continue to fly as normal 
after the UK has left the EU."
Load-Date: March 8, 2019
End of Document
E O'Leary would like woman to lead Ryanair mainline Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary would like a 
woman to take over as head of the group's mainline oper....
 E O'Leary would like woman to lead Ryanair mainline; Ryanair chief 
executive Michael O'Leary would like a woman to take over as head of the 
group's mainline operation, although his preference for an internal 
candidate appears to limit his options in this regard.
Flight International
March 7, 2019
Copyright 2019 DVV Media International Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 308 words
Body
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary would like a woman to take over as head of the group's mainline operation, 
although his preference for an internal candidate appears to limit his options in this regard.
Explaining at the A4E Summit in Brussels on 6 March that he expected the new chief executive to be in place by 
year-end, O'Leary expressed a desire to "break from the past". At the same time, however, he suggests that a 
current Ryanair employee is the most likely appointee.
"If I had a choice, I'd have a female, just because that would be a very significant break with the past in Ryanair," he 
says, adding that he thinks "it's likely to be an internal candidate, because they understand the business".
Of the nine "senior executives" listed on Ryanair's website, just one is a woman: chief risk officer Carol Sharkey.
"I would want somebody who has the opposite of my limited skillset," says O'Leary. "So, somebody female, 
empathetic, caring, kind. As opposed to a rapacious bastard like me for the last 30 years. I think it would be very 
good for the company."
He clarifies that the process to identify the new mainline chief executive will not begin until Ryanair has released its 
full-year results.
"The plan is, we'll advertise internally and externally, do the full-year results in May, we'll run the ads at that stage, 
we'll recruit sometime in September and October and have them in place by the end of the year," he says.
O'Leary suggests that an external candidate is unlikely to take up the role unless an "exceptional" person applies.
E O'Leary would like woman to lead Ryanair mainline Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary would like a 
woman to take over as head of the group's mainline oper....
As part of a restructuring at Ryanair, O'Leary is stepping up to a group chief executive role. Eventually, the heads of 
Ryanair mainline, Laudamotion and to-be-renamed Ryanair Sun will report to him. There are also tentative plans for 
a Ryanair UK unit, depending on the outcome of Brexit negotiations.
Load-Date: March 7, 2019
End of Document
O'Leary joins KLM ? Europe's airline chiefs pick fantasy job-swaps "Imagine you could take over the airline of 
one of your co-panellists for one week. Which one....
O'Leary joins KLM? Europe's airline chiefs pick fantasy job-swaps; "Imagine 
you could take over the airline of one of your co-panellists for one week. 
Which one and why?" asked moderator Richard Quest, to laughter from an 
expectant A4E audience.
Flight International
March 7, 2019
Copyright 2019 DVV Media International Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 311 words
Body
Many a true word is spoken in jest, they say.
That phrase was perhaps pertinent during the closing chief executive panel at the A4E Summit on 6 March.
"Imagine you could take over the airline of one of your co-panellists for one week. Which one and why?" asked 
moderator Richard Quest, to laughter from an expectant audience.
Big shoes to fill?
Ed Telling Photography
Lufthansa chief executive Carsten Spohr was first to respond.
"I would take Willie's job because I am jealous of his home market in London," he replies in reference to IAG's 
British Airways, playing it relatively safe.
IAG chief Willie Walsh did not chose such a safe answer, however, instead picking a topic that his often been the 
subject of industry rumours.
"I would take KLM and spend that week convincing them that they should be part of IAG," he says.
But Walsh won't be doing a job swap with KLM chief executive Pieter Elbers. Instead, the latter says he fancies the 
idea of running a low-cost competitor.
"I would take Ryanair and I would show customers that they could really have an enjoyable journey if they pay a 
few pounds more," he states.
O'Leary joins KLM ? Europe's airline chiefs pick fantasy job-swaps "Imagine you could take over the airline of 
one of your co-panellists for one week. Which one....
This prompts Ryanair chief Michael O’Leary to rethink his answer.
"I’ve changed my mind in the last few seconds. I was originally going to say Carsten so I could [experience] what it 
feels like to own Germany, Austria and Switzerland," O’Leary says.
"[But] I’ve changed [to KLM], so that I can encourage the Dutch government to buy more of Air France," he 
continues, in reference to earlier comments that state investment in an airline is bad for the respective business and 
therefore benefits Ryanair.
And what of EasyJet’s chief executive, Johan Lundgren?
"I’d take all of them," he says, to more laughs from the audience.
"I noticed that nobody wanted to take [EasyJet]," he then observes, adding that he had decided to take that as "a 
massive compliment".
Load-Date: March 7, 2019
End of Document
